Dark brown with no carbonation. Malty dark candi breadyness, molasses and dark fruits. Full bodied. Good body, with some yeasty dullness. Not as great as expected.

Draught. Pours dark brown reddish, virtually no head. Sweetish ripe plums mostly in aroma. Taste has ripe plums, dark fruits and vinous notes in it. Feels a bit flat on the whole. Has a vinous aftertaste. Gets a bit smoother towards the finish.

11.2 oz bottle from 2010. Pours very dark brown with a small foamy head that fades normally but never completely goes away. Aroma is surprisingly faint but still good. Dark fruit, raisins, cinnamon, Belgian yeast, brown sugar, apples, and musty wet wood. Taste starts off moderately sweet with rich plums, apples, and cherries. The finish has a red wine feel to it and it mixes well with the Belgian yeast aftertaste. Medium to thick body, slightly chewy and sticky mouthfeel. Another good one from Struise.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2013 A dark brown to black beer, with a small light brown head. In the nose there is are light roasted malts, caramel malts. overripe fruits and cherries. It is a full bodied beer, with a average carbonation, close to flat. In the taste there are light roasted coffee malts, caramel malts, fruits, banana, light sour, cherries and alcohol. The aftertaste is soft, light alcohol, and creamy. A very nice beer, a better version of the wonderful pannepot

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Candied malt and thick quad-like taste all around. Wish Id had this before the Ypres, which stunned my palate for a bit, but its warming up nicely. Booze hardly detectable. A flavour of plums and apple just before ripeness. Dark whiskey coloured without much head or lacing. Tap at Ebenezer Kezars.

Bottle bought @ bieresgourmet.be. 2009 vintage. Pours tiny hazy reddish wooden brown (late pours pour incredibly murky) with a rather small frothy and fizzy reddish beige head that quickly dissipates without leaving much trace on the glass. Smell is slightly sweet, malty and tiny dusty with sweet dark bread, biscuits, oatmeal cookies, raisins, figs, alcohol, vanilla fudge, caramel, St Johns wort, caraway, walnuts, roasted hazelnuts and subtle hints of bourbon. Taste is tiny sweet, slightly bitter, tiny sour and malty with sweet dark bread, caramel, biscuits, oatmeal cookies, caraway, St Johns wort, lemon zest, tamarind, assorted roasted nuts, alcohol, vanilla fudge, charred wood, hay, pepper corns, raisins, dates and figs. Mouthfeel is soft, round, slightly boozy, tiny spicy astringent, tiny tart and medium to full bodied. Finish is slightly bitter and malty with toasted malts, oatmeal cookies, biscuits, vanilla fudge, tamarind, dates, raisins, figs and bread spices. Tasty but want to try a fresher bottle...

2010 vintage. Pours dark brown with a medium brown head that falls quickly. Scents of molasses, cinnamon, raisin, vanilla oak. Tastes of molasses, mint, spice and a hint of smoke. Finishes dry with some heat from the alcohol. Nice.

Nice dark brown color, fizzy out of the bottle but it disappears quickly. Rich, fruity aroma, almost sugary, but indistinct. I get some dried fruit and some coffee, molasses. Flavor is drier than normal pannepot, more bitter. Coffee and alcohol notes in the front, a bit of ash, almond. Very nice and refined, an elegant beer.
11oz bottle pours a hazy dark brown with a small khaki head. Sweet malt aroma. Caramel dark fruit and a slight wood taste.
Vintage 2006, dark brown, a bit beige foam. Low carbonation. Full body. Aroma of dark fruit, raisins and chocolate. Alcohol is very well hidden. Very complex, perfect balance sweet/bitter.

33 cl flaske, 10 %, købt i Den Belgiske Ølbutik, 21. august 2013.
Sort/brun lettere uklar belgisk ale med flygtigt moccafarvet skum, ca. 1/2 cm tykkelse. Meget skøn og vinøs aroma af tørret frugt, engelsk plumcake, og den første smag efterlader én åndeløs. Fyldig fyldig smag af blomme/sveske og andet tørretfrugt. En øl, man bare har lyst at skylle rundt i munden og tænde alle smagslamper. Fin blødhed og moderat kulsyreindhold. Balancen imellem sødmen fra frugten og kandissukkeret, bitterheden og det let syrlige er perfekt. God kraftig alkoholfylde, men aldrig for kraftigt. Fantastisk lang eftersmag. Et mesterværk!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Disappointed with this beer. 2010 bottling. Drank yesterday. Lost a lot of its sweetness (Im assuming from other ratings) and wasnt very complex. It was ok, but curious to try it fresh. Ehhh.
Bottle poured into glass. This one is really complex with a lot of flavors happening. Hints of dark fruits, yeast, bread, raisins and some woody aspects as well. Really enjoyable.

Bottle - Vintage 2008 - Dark fruit, brown sugar and wine barrel. Cloudy brown with a thin brown head. Brown sugar, dark fruits and mild alcohol. The brown sugar overwhelms at first but finishes nicely with some barrel notes. As this beer sits for a bit, the heavy sugars fade and the sourish dark fruit comes to life. A very nice beer.

750ml bottle (2010 vintage) [Thanx David!]. Dark brown colour with small to average, frothy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, tan head. Minimally vinous aroma, lots of dark and dried fruit. Taste is rich, minimally sweet, hints of dark and dried fruit, plum, raisin and the like, hints of toffee, chocolate, an oaky touch. Superbly balanced, not too sweet, wonderfully smooth, soft palate.

One of the greatest beers ever. Silky smooth and dessert like rich taste with tons of dried and candied fruit as well as toffee, caramel and molasses. A sultry wooden and earthy Calvados barrel flavour pervades perfectly making this one of the best belgiian beers around.

On tap, clear dark brown pour with small quickly dissapating tan head. Aroma of fruits, caramel and hint of oak. Taste of caramel, raisins, brown sugar, slight cherry, spices and very subtle oak. Medium bodied with lower carbonation, excellent tasty beer.
Fick tag på en flaska från 2007 i Danmark!! Svart med ljusbrunt skum och mycket kolsyra! Portvin, kaffe och choklad! Mycket bra öl!

Medium brown with brown flakes. Thin tan head. Apple-cherry pie, buttery pastry crust, bread, bread crust. Medium body/ carbonation. Flavor brown sugar, spiced raisin bread. Apple-cherry pie. More mellow than the regular, less tart cherry apple in flavor.

33 cl. bottle at Kulminator, 2008 Vintage. Hazy, dark brown colour with a medium sized, tanned head. Sweet aroma with dark, dried fruits - also fresh, exotic fruits, a hearthy amount of caramel malts, spices and a light hint of oak. Alcohol. Taste is sweet. Full body, oily feel and a soft carbonation. Long lasting sweet finish with overripe fruits, brown sugar, licorice and spices. A pleasent, light burn from the alcohol. Another superb beer from De Struise Brouwers.

2010 bottle. dark brown pour, with one finger of persistent, foamy beige head. toffee, spice, malt, and sour dark fruits in the nose. more toffee and caramel malts in the taste, with candy sugar, dark fruits, and some mellow wood notes. creamy and almost syrupy - really an incredible texture. very lightly sweet finish of coffee, caramel, and toffee. well-balanced, and an absolutely superb beer.

2007 bottle from gluglugburp. Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aromas of alcohol, caramel, dark fruits. The taste is sweeter but well balanced. Although this isnt my style, this is quite tasty. The taste has a little tang and a little heat and some coffee in the aftertaste.  An oily mouth feel with perfect carbonation after 6 years. Very well done.

Bottle @ Cervezorama. Reserva 2010. Brown colour, almost black, with a beige head with good asting. Aroma is malty with notes of toasted and candy sugar, caramel, toffee and wood. Flavor is very similar as aroma and is dominated by notes of caramel, raisins, ripe fruit, toffee, candy sugar and slightly coffee. The final is slightly sweet with notes of caramel and mild alcoholic. The sensation in the mouth is rounded, creamy and dense.

Purchased at Discount Liquor in Milwaukee, WI; enjoyed after a stressful work day on a nice cool summer night right by the window. Appearance is a dark charcoal / very dark brown with a moderate tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, plum, oak, a bit more subdued than the original. Taste goes down with a slippery/syrupy mouthfeel, rich in dark fruit. Deceptive, its 10% ABV and certainly doesnt taste like it, also has a sherry like quality like the original. I actually like the original a bit more though, the oak seems to be taking a little bit away, but its still an exceptional brew.

Taster on tap at World of Beer - Tempe. Pours a dark copper with a dark tan head. Aroma of heavy oak resin, touch of raisin, and some dark cherry. Oak is the primary component of the taste, also a spiced cedar and cinnamon tone. Caramelized sugar and chocolate-covered dates take hold after awhile. Very velvety texture. Nice, but I think I prefer the regular Pannepot, as the oak aging has muted some of the best characteristics of the Belgian yeast.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2017 Bottle. Aroma of oak, caramelised malt and red fruit. Taste of oak, red fruit, port wine, mild vanilla and spices. The Pannepot improved. This used to be better and more complex, rating is for a newer bottle.

2008 bottle. Pours a somewhat murky brown with not much head. The aroma has some raisins, figs, molasses, vanilla, wet wood. Tastes like a dark fruity sweet and sort of musty grape. I have to say, I was expecting much more. Maybe I would like this more if it was fresher.
2008 Vintage. Oaky and rich smelling, with a medium brown color. Smooth, sweet and malty. Light carbonation and hint of oaky/sherry flavor.
Draft at Churchkey. Poured a dark brown color with ruby notes and a small tan head. Aroma was dark fruits, caramel notes, sweet malts. Flavor was light malts, dark fruits, caramel. Pretty good.

4 oz. served into a tasting snifter at ChurchKey. From notes; 2010 vintage.

A: Pours a dark ruby color. The head is little more than a thin khaki film. Still, its very stout-like in appearance.

S: There are some evident tones of nuts, dark fruits, oak, and spicing here, however its not nearly as evocative as I expected. What is here, at least, is well balanced and pleasurable.

T: The opening is mildly nutty and spicy. This will progress into a middle of earthy toffee, with a light oak finish. Solid complexity, but the flavors themselves arent blowing my mind.

M: Its medium bodied in texture. The alcohol (seemingly in typical De Struise fashion) is well concealed in spite of its (also seemingly in typical De Struise fashion) dry finish. Very drinkable, as well.

O: Decent, but pretty disappointing. The only brew from De Struise this night that didnt wow me. Mayhaps the keg isnt in fantastic shape? This would probably be better if it were bottle conditioned, in fairness.
2010 vintage. Refines the strengths of an already great brew. Taste is a little more nuanced and the alcohol is less apparent than the regular Pannepot.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2013 75cl bottle. Blind tasting. Shared with Mathieu87
APPEARANCE: black beer with a red shine. Little to no foam.
NOSE: little whiskey nose, some chocolate, coffee, dark fruits, mostly grapes.
TASTE: sweet, strong chocolate, molasses, somewhat fruity, some wood.
Really let down by the 75cl bottles for some reason, liked the 33cl bottles better in my memory... looking forward to trying the 33cl bottle one again though! 8/3/8/4/17
Re-rate  33cl bottle. Vintage 2009.
APPEARANCE: pitch black beer, small unstable beige head.
NOSE: alcohol, wood, molasses, dense chocolate, fruity, red fruits.
TASTE: wine like, fruity, chocolate. Amazing in total!

Been waiting to try this one for awhile. On tap at Über - congrats on 7 years! Aroma of chocolate, dark fruit, smoke, leather, chocolate again, caramel. Complex and intriguing. Cola brown pour, murky, minimal ring of tan bubbles. Taste - yum. A little tangy at the end, lots of chocolate and smoke. Full body, some carb, silky/syrupy texture. Long smoky chocolate sweet finish. Very nice treat. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Currently drinking whilst typing (2009 Reserva). WOW! The aroma is amazing and complex, full of deep rich raisin, dark forest fruits, cherry, port, sweet breadiness, sweet barrel aged alcohol notes. Pours as a dark brown vessel with a full tan coloured head towering above. A ridiculously complex taste completely steals the show, I would say the closest thing to a Westvleteren without a doubt. It is laden with rich dark sweet malts, raisin, cherry, fruity Belgian bready yeast, plum and a well disguised alcohol note with a warming character. Incredibly smooth and full bodied palate with very gentle carbonation and a long complex finish. Overall, this is a true goliath in the beer world, its near on perfect and the closest thing to a Westvleteren 12, obviously the two have very subtle differences but if you want a mind blowing yet affordable beer from one of the greatest breweries in the world; then look no further than the Pannepot Reserva!
Simply perfect. Nothing to envy to Rochefort 10, even to Westvleteren. Undoubtedly, one of the best beers Ive ever had. Colossal, impressive, superb...a unique beer.

Poirs dark dark brown with low to no latte brown head
Aromas of tar, tobacco, liqourise, chaerries, dades
Taste absolutely great! Matured perfectly. Warming alcohol, creamy palate. Loads of special b, cherries, oak, raisins, dades.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2009 vintage. Rich and sweet aroma. caramel, dark fruit, bit of alcohol, some spices, something roasty. 
Tastes about the same.  smooth and creamy. Supremely balanced.  Aroma plus malt and some earthy/woody taste, which mixes dry and sweet flavors.

2010 vintage. Dark brown/black pour with the aromas hitting me as soon as I cracked the bottle. Big aromas of malt, yeast, dried fruit, and oak. Really complex. The flavor doesnt disappoint either, rich and robust. A really great brew, the oak aging seems to have brought out the best in this one!

2009 vintage - rated 6/12/13. Dark brown with meadium creamy lasting brown head. Fantastic rich and delicate aroma; sweet and complex; caramel, dark fruit, touch of alcohol, some spices, a bit of roasty/coffee. Flavor follows right through. Full body; luxurious, smooth and creamy. Supremely balanced. In comparison to the regular brew, this is more mellow malt presence with a definite woody character, adding a bit of dryness to the sweet/bitter/alcohol balance.

2009 draft at Eulogy. pours dark brown to black. nose is raisins, dates, brown malt, and molasses. first sip is similar with beautiful oaky notes. finish is fruity with prunes and quince paste. awesome.

Draft of the 2009 vintage at a beer event at Eulogy in June 2013. Dark pour. Syrupy body. Lots of strong intense barrel aged goodness. The deep red fruit in the normal Pannepot has darkened and caramelized. Very, very rich! Brandied cherries. Caramel raisins. Vanila bourbon. Chocolate prunes. Notably higher alcohol than expected but the aging has smoothed out the finish. Tremendous!

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2013 bottle @ home, 2009. this is one of my favourite beers. nice thick head.  
yes the oak did it again. chocolate, nuts, caramel. I love it!

2011 Bottle. Pours a murky dark brown with coarse, light brown head. Settles in minutes with no lacing. Aroma is fruity, plum, stone fruit, mild alcohol. Flavor is fruity, plum, fig, dark stone fruit, with a malty, toffee, and mild alcohol finish. The alcohol is well masked as expected, beer is very well balanced. Soft carbonation with a medium body and smooth texture. Dark, fruity, rich, a tasty brew.
(bottle 02/06-2013) very large brown fast fading head, black color, smooth complex taste, oak taste. Bottle 2009.
Bottle from 2009. Dark beer with a beige head. Dried dark fruits, vanilla and chocolate aroma. Roasted malt, dried dark fruits and vanilla flavour. Lovely beer :-)

Sample from 2010 bottle at the Memorial Day Deck Beers tasting on 05/27/2013: This beer pours an opaque cola color with a thin light beige head that diminishes steadily to a dense film. Small patches of lacing. Port wine, yeast and caramel in the nose. Full-bodied with flavors of raisins, Belgian yeast, caramel malt and vanilla. The finish is sweet with a dark fruit aftertaste. Good beer all around.

330mL bottle from Belmont Station. 2010 vintage. Westvleteren goblet.

A: Fizzes up from the glass. Very dark mahogany to the point of nearly being black. Creamy head disintegrates into leftovers. Leaves some pretty nice legs.

N: Greeted by a cavalcade of walnuts, sweet malt, and oak. Theres a touch of molasses about this. Some cola and plenty of clove. Cinnamon, peppercorn and caramel. Very aromatic and pleasing if disjointed.

T: Heavy on the wood with a hint of savory flavors over the top of a bread sweetness. Tastes very exotic if a little overspice and almost funky. Shows some biting astringency. A little bit of soy sauce/salt.

M: Dense and full with lively carbonation. 

O: Id much prefer the base beer, the Monks Ale or the Grand Reserva. Though this beer is very well rounded, its almost got a wild element to it.  Disappointed, I admit.

2008 Vintage
Aroma is rich and malty. Lots of caramel and toffee, moderate nuttiness and treacle, light chocolate and roast. Moderate raisin and prune with light fig and dried fruit. Faint phenolic spice. 
Pours dark brown with some ruby highlights. Medium thick tan head that recedes fairly quickly to a film on top and along the edges. 
Flavor has a moderately sweet character. The flavor is strongly malty with toffee, dark caramel, moderate treacle, light chocolate, roastiness and nuttiness. Moderate bitterness. Moderate fruitiness with fig, cherry, raisin and stone fruit. Moderate phenolic spice note in the finish that blends nicely with the light alcohol spice. Medium light oak character with a nice sherry note. 
Medium to medium full bodied with medium carbonation. Low astringency and moderate alcohol warmth. The beer is sweet but not sticky at all. 
Overall a delicious beer with a very balanced character. This is what I would expect from a big De Struise beer. Very nice malt character.

2009 vintage Poured into a glass. Dark reddish brown pour with a khaki head. Nose is sweet dark fruits and vanilla with some Oak and yeast. Taste is a bit funky sweet up front with chocolate, figs, raisins. that quickly gets laced in with lots of wood/oak character that supports it all the way to a bitter sweet burnt brown sugar finish. A little on the sweet side, but complex and entirely impressive. Very smooth and gentle carbonation.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2013 Pours dark brown with some ruby red notes, small off white head, disappears quickly. Aroma is caramel, dark fruits, molasses, spices. Taste is sweet, malty, caramel, spices, bread, yeast. Medium to full body, low carbonation. Nice lingering sweet, malty aftertaste, the oak is present in the taste though subtle. Very nice brew.
Definitely mellower than the non-reserve version. Has an almost tangy taste to it.

33 cl bottle from Etre Gourmet. 2009 Vintage. Pours dark brown/reddish
with a medium brown head. Leaves a good lacing. Aroma of dark fruits, fig, prune, raisins, bread. Very complex and nice aroma. Flavour is is same as aroma. Alcohol taste is completely hidden. Very complex and very well balanced. Full body, medium carbonation, low bitterness, slick mouthfeel.

330 ml bottle into chalice, 2009 vintage.  Pours murky dark reddish brown color with a small khaki head with decent retention, that reduces to a thin lace cap that lingers.  Minimal glass lacing with some light streaming carbonation.  Aromas of big raisin, prune, fig, molasses, toast, clove, pepper, oak, light roast, brown bread, and yeast earthiness.  Damn nice aromas with good balance and complexity of malt and fruity/spicy notes with moderate oak presence.  Taste of raisin, prune, fig, molasses, toast, toffee, clove, pepper, oak, brown bread, light roast, and toasted earthiness.  Lingering notes of dark fruit, molasses, toast, toffee, oak, clove, pepper, brown bread, light roast, and earthiness on the finish for a while.  Fantastic complexity and balance of malt and fruity/spicy flavors; with moderate oak presence and zero cloying flavors after the finish.  Medium carbonation and fairly full bodied; with a creamy and slick mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a fantastic oak aged quadrupel.  Big complexity and great balance of flavors; and quite smooth to sip on.  A highly enjoyable offering.

Beautiful taste and aroma , it's a strong beer But you can't feel The alcohol In The beer . I really recomend this beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Refrigerated 11.2 oz. brown 2009 bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours dark brown with small medium brown highlights.  Little lacing, medium body, medium carbonation, and dark fruit aroma.  Taste is oak, dark fruit, and a hint of alcohol which peaks every once and a while.  Complex but still pretty easy to drink.  Probably past its prime.
Appearance in the dark dark brown with a slight head.  Aroma of toffee and caramel.  Taste rather sweet and long on the palate

Bottle at home bought at the schoolyard in 2009. Aroma is full plum raisin caramel and a touch old Christmas pud booziness. Really sark caramel colour with a little ruby. Light swirling tan head and some legs. Flavour is rich deep rum raisin oak and roast come through in the finish but it is perfectly balanced. Long mellow duration. Palate is velvety. Great beer.

Clear black colour, beige head. Aroma of chocolate, liquorice, roasted malts, apple, vanilla and malts. Sweet flavour, chocolate, malts, vanilla, dried fruits, hint of wood. Finish chocolate, bourbon, quite alcoholic.
Good beer.
(Draught @ ZBF, Leuven 2013)
I smell chocolate, dried fruits, vanilla, malts. The rich sweet flavours make me smile and give a glimp of heaven.
ZBF Festival 2013 -  Black with thick, creamy head. Thick, oily and warming from the alcohol. Its very rich. I dont get much from the barrel on this one but the treacly, burnt sugars are nice.
Absolut världsklass. Lagrats till det bättre. Kjellander tjatar om vem som är fullast egentligen. Han vinner. Fantastisk kanderad sötma. Hell yeah

Bottled, thx rlgk. Pours black with a small brown head. Smells figs, raisins, sweet, chocolate, abit alcohol. Tastes creamy dark chocolate, figs, raisins, abit alcohol,  roasted malt with a similar finish.
Bottle 0.75l at Pikkulintu, Helsinki. 2006 vintage. Colour is reddish brown with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Dark fruits, plums, Belgian yeast, wood and sourness. Reminds me of red wine.

2009 bottle slightly chilled.  black pour, darker than expected, poor head retention.   Quite full bodied.  Slightly sharp to start. Typical raisins, slight coffee, semi dry finish.  Taste is like a less intense version of their XXXX - nice but less sweet with a more complex finish.  Very nice beer overall.

2008 Bottle. An opaque light cola brown with a small off-white head, lots of sediment.  Aroma is heavy caramel, sweet red wine, port, apples, dark fruits.  This is one I can just keep smelling for hours.  Taste is a little bit of a letdown, medium sweet with loads of caramel, a slight bitterness, not very complex.  Finish is disappointingly weak.  Medium bodied, moderate carbonation.  Still though, one of the best smelling beers Ive ever had.

Dark beer with creamy foam head that is stable and long lasting on the beer. 
Great fresh taste with balanced hop bitterness that is in harmony with the alcohol level of this beer. 

---Rated By the Belleketels

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2014 Dark mudda. Aroma is fruit (tangerine, orange) and some spice. Taste is lovely - the same as the regular pannepot, but the fruits dont predomindate quite as much here, which I prefer. The reserva has a richness and deepness unlike any other strong ale ive had. Overall, one of my favourite strong ales, and one id get again.

Draft at Torst. 2009 vintage.  Pours blackish brown with a thin tan head. Aroma is huge of raisins, prunes and figs. Taste is of dark fruits, caramel, spice and some maltiness. There is a slight bitterness in the finish. Incredibly well balanced and very tasty.

2008 vintage. Big Thanks adnielsen !Pours a deep mahogany color with a big three finger fizzy khaki foam that settles... Aromas are molasses, vanilla, warm spice,  walnut, cocoa.... the palate is smooth and velvety with great kola nut, plum, vanilla, burnt sugar, wet wood, bordeaux wine ! I absolutely love this beer.

2009 vintage tasted alongside 2011 Pannepot and 2011 Pannepeut. 33 cL bottle from Binnys Beverage Depot in Chicago, served in a stem glass. Pours hazy chestnut with a tiny tan head that fades to a few bubbles. The nose has notes of sour fruit and oak along with caramel, plum, vermouth, caramel and subtle chocolate. The flavour is moderately sweet with toasty malts, molasses, oak and subtle spice. There is a subtle sour note that persists in the background. The finish is long and malty with oak and dark fruit. On the palate it is medium-full with a smooth, milky texture and soft carbonation. Overall, a tasty and elegant chocolatey, oaky strong ale. Very tasty. 2013-03-14
At BBF. Pours dark brown with little tan head. Raisins, chocolate, caramel aroma. Same for aroma, with some malty character, roastness and wood. Good beer.

Pannepot Reserva 2009: 
Colere bruno, mogano. Schiuma abbondante che lascia residui sul bicchiere. Aroma complessissimo: alcol, caramello, fichi, datteri, frutta secca e un sentore tannico. Al palato ingresso dolce con le note di vaniglia, e cioccolato al latte e lalcol che la rende calda e vellutata. Assurda, complessissima. A fine sorso interviene un lievo amaro luppolato e caffettoso. Tutta la sorsata è accompagnata da un sentore legnoso e tannico. Voto:4.7

<<>>Pannepot Reserva 2007
Beh! che dire se la 2009 era gia una branda la 2007 è stata una delle migliori birre che ho provato. Lunico difetto è che finisce. Non si presenta proprio bene. Un geyser di schiuma fuoriesce appena stappata. Fortuna che avevo messo il bicchiere sotto e tra la disperazione e un leggero stato confusionale sono riuscito a recuperare il prezioso nettare. Colore: come la 2009. Cosi come laroma forse un pò meglio legato e levigato grazie alla maturazione. Appena bevuta entri in un stato di trance e inizi gia a deprimerti perchè già sai che finirà prima o poi. Tra le tante (e stupende) note che si riescono a distinguere sono vaniglia, datteri, fichi, cioccolato. Il tannico e lalcol la rendono clomplessa quasi quanto un whisky. La cosa che stupisce è che le note sono perfettamente ammalgamate tra loro. Sembra di bere seta morbidosa e liquida che accarezza ogni singolo mm della tua bocca. C A P O L A V O R O  punto e basta. Voto: 4.9
Voto medio: 4.8

11.2oz bottle ( vintage 2008) - pours opaque brown with dark orange floaties, thin beige head and decent lacing. Nose is basement aromas, plums, alcohol and wood. Flavor adds fruitiness and I want to say apricot. Complex. Sweet with a tangy finish. I should have chilled it a little longer. A stand our beer in a long line of contenders.
UPDATED: JUN 7, 2013 In tap at Maxs. Aroma is light, but taste is dark fruits, sweetness, oak, wonderful.

I have tried the fishermans ale which was fantastic, but this is truly exceptional. First, the labeling on the beer is awesome. It looks like an impressionist painting. The aroma is rather dull, but do not be fooled. This is a lovely complex brew. It is the crown jewel of the brand. It starts out with lovely chocolate maltiness and finishes dry and a bit tart. It is pure silk in the mouth.

2008 bottle (at Kulminator in 2013): Incredibly complex ... where do I begin? Immensely rich with intricate notes of dark-fruit (raisin, fig, prune), chocolate, cooked caramel, brown sugar, and Sugar Daddy candy. Amazingly, it didnt seem overly sweet, as the alcohol, subtle roast and bitterness balanced it out well. Chewy, milkshake-like texture. After every sip I discovered new flavors, and I didnt want the beer to end.

Bottle vintage 2009. Pours unclear red amber with a moderate tan head. Aroma is caramel, marzipan, very estery, plum, pear, banana, oak, overripe fruit, burnt caramel, prune, light booze and a tiny oxidized note, quite smoky at times. Taste: Medium sweet+ and bitter with tart note. Body is is near full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. Finishes dry, oak, anise and warming. Great balance, complex aroma - incredibly accomplished beer.

2009 Pours dark brown with on off-white head. Great aromas of caramel and dried fruits. Chocolate and coffee notes. Wow, this is yummy, complex and well balanced. A long finish and a great brew. I need to age a few of these.
On tap @La Tape, Madrid. Some coffe aromas. Pours dark with amber tones, nice tan head, creamy and compact. Taste is too sweet, with warming aftertaste. Enjoyable.

2008 Bottle. Pours a cloudy beown with large beige head that lasts awhile. The aroma is brown sugar and yeast. Medium mouthfeel with strong oak and dark fruits with lingering light dry finish. Hides alcohol well, a very impressive Belgian strong ale.
Reserva 2008 at Demervallei. Pours brown with reddish tinge. Aroma is one of rich sweetness. Medium body, creamy, very smooth.

Bottle, 2007. Dark chestnut brown with a small light brown head that leaves a bit of lacing. Aroma is port wine, dried fruit, prunes, wood, caramel, mild coffee. Taste is heavy sweet, full body, oily texture, carbonation is lively. Long finish with port wine, oak and caramel. Very nice to sip on with so many things to pick up in the aroma.
Bottle 2009. Pours brown with thin tan lacing. Big fig and basement aroma lots of caramel. Taste is stale sweet plums and fig.

33 cl. 2008 bottle.  Thanks GT!  Pours dark brown with a small dark biege head.  Aroma of dark fruit, malt, toffee, caramel, and spices.  Taste is malt, plums, cherries, chocolate, toffee, spices, wood, and just a bit of alcohol.  Simply superb!

Poured a watery looking dark brown with a thick tan head. Aroma of soft malt and alcohol infused dark fruits. Smooth, medium to full body, flavour of dark fruits and some caramel malt, some vsanilla smoothness with a slight bittersweet toffee aftertaste.
Brutal cerveza con toques achocolatados, no esperaba menos de esta cerveza, toda una explosión de sabor en mi boca.

Pours from the bottle with a warm chestnut brown color with quite a number of floating specks of sediment entrained therein, and a big, foamy beige head on top. The aroma is sadly a bit muted, but it does convey some nice notes of dark brown sugar and dried grains. The flavor is certainly more assertive, with moderately rich, dry toffee-like sweetness, some mild floral and dried herb characteristics, and some slightly tangy yeast. The medium body and light, fine carbonation do a very nice job lightening the profile without taking away substance. Overall, this lacks the same dry, fruity depth of the best in this class, but it is mouth-pleasing and quite a bit more drinkable than its 10% ABV would suggest.

So awesome~  this is right up there with the best of them. Definitely liked this one as much as the grand reserva, maybe more.  But this is a 2008 bottle and the grand was drunk a year ago or so.  Anyway, aroma is alco-esters, wet dough, spice, anise, caramel. Appearance is dark brown with red hues shining in the light, thin froth, good legs.  Taste is bready, rich malty toasty cereal, and very smooth great mouthfeel.  Palate is warm, with a good mix of hop and spice to calm down the abv, its hidden well but there. I really highly recommend this and any other Struisse beers!

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2013 33cl bottle (2009). Pours deep mahogany with thin off-white head and plenty of lacing throughout. Aroma is oak, deep dark fruit, sherry, lightly sweet vanilla pod, vinous notes. Taste is full and beautifully balanced: wonderful dark fruits mix effortlessly with the oaked tones - great depth. Light vanilla notes, yeast complexity, bready malt, light caramel. All comes together impeccably. Mouthfeel is full and silky smooth. No hint of alcohol heat. Nice residual woodiness and dark fruit notes. This is a tremendous strong ale, absolutely impeccable.
Geweldig bier, ziet er goed uit, vol van smaak en romig. Geweldige brouwerij.

2009 Bottle, so 3 years old approximately. Drank next to a 2005 Grand Reserva and 2011 regular Pannepot.  

It pours a deep clear brown with reddish tinge. The initial tan head gives quickly. The aroma is a rich sweet bread and yeast with very ripe dark fruit and a little nice oxidation. Its just a little more hot and full with fruit esters than the PGR and much richer than the standard. The aromas just keeps going and pulls you in. Flavor is the same with a some spice like cinnamon and clove taking hold in the middle and somewhat woody bitter end. Its moderately sweet but in incredible balance with.  Its just a little less heavy, rich, and warm than the PGR, must be the calvados and age.  The PGR at 7 years is less lively and has a dead yeast character (not off putting in the slightest).  This one is very luxurious with a lively creamy mouthfeel and warming, woody end.  This is a masterpiece to say the least. Its drinking perfectly right now.  If I had to guess 7 years is getting past the peak of the PGR, thought it is still awesome.
2009 reserva, lovely sticky dark goodness. Perfectly balanced coffee, dark chocolate, dark fruits & liqourice with a nice warm boozy finish.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2013 Vintage 2009 - Mild taste with  a touch of coffee. Malty taste with light subtle bitterness. smell has a touch of red cabbage. Dark,black color with minimal brown hat. Aftertaste lasts long, has  a touch  of dryness like red wine. It isnt quitte as full bodied as the original though, I think.

Vintage 2008 33 cl. Bottle @ home. Pours a brown reddish color with no head. 
The aromas are dominated by malty goodness, ripe fruit abd alcohol. The taste is sweet and alcoholic. Somme bitterness. Good balance.. all in all a bit overrated.. but good

2009 edition.  pours a dark hazy reddish amber, with a decent and lingering tan head.  huge, spicy nose, lots of raisins and astringent spices combined with strong oak and a nutty malt.  very dry taste, with dark grapes, figs, plums, and some cherry mixing with a strong woody flavor, and a nutty, earthy malt flavor.  a little bit of grassy hops on the back side.  basically, it tastes like it smells, very complex and dry, with oak being the thing that stands out the most from the melange.  very dry finish, almost astringent, with a good hop bitterness, but virtually no sweetness.  great creamy mouthfeel, coating and bubbly.  overall, a pretty fantastic beer, but not quite in my pantheon with st. bernardus and rochefort 10.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2014 2009. At first sniff, I got prunes, spices, yeast, sour apples, banana peel, figs, and dark cherries. It was amazing enough already, but then I let it sit for a bit and dove my nose into the glass again and, oh, Lordy! It was the greatest thing ever. Mountains upon mountains of toffee, all bursting with fruity esters and spices. The alcohol is barely perceivable, if at all. The taste is sweet and fruity tart, with residual bitterness. It evokes figs, dark cherries, caramel, and apple cider up front and culminates with mellow, woody undertones. The mouthfeel is smooth as silk, with minor carbonation and a medium body. Otherworldly!

Bottle from the Bottle Shop, Canterbury 221212
Dark rich caramel brown, frothy off white head that dissipates to thin rime around glass, some lacing
Aroma - Very malty sweet, raisins, figs, dark fruits, some dark honey, sweet caramel malts,  touch of toffee, soft spices, some of that Belgian yeast, almost no booze, aromatic, reminds one of Rochefort 10, this is very complex
Taste as above with dark candy sugars, very complex, very malty, dark fruits, spices, touch of chocolate, soft sherry, complex yeast esters, only slight hint of booze, getting a touch of wood, very rich flavour
Palate - Medium carb, full body, sweet palate, very smooth. Finish as main flavour, smooth, very fruity and malty with some warming booze in the finish
Overall - I would love to try normal Pannepot after this. This beer is just phenomenal - it ticks all the boxes. I have to re-rate Rochefort 10 soon and see how it compares.

Bottle at tuulensuu, tampere. Bottled 2009. Dark brown color, almost black. Small white head disappears quickly. Aroma of plums, raisins, banana, honey. Balanced taste of plum, sweetness, some hops, quite high co2, medium-long aftertaste, some oak and licorice. Very nice.

2008 bottle.  Murky brown color out of the bottle with a very small head that settled into an attractive ring.  Intoxicating aroma of ripe fruit, thick sweetness, warming alcohol and happiness.  Flavors of apples, pair, toffee, vanilla and some oak.  It seemed a little thin. I wonder what this would have been like fresher.

Bottled, 2009. Pours totally black with a light brown head. Aroma is sweet malt, roasted notes, dark fruits, caramel, oak and spices. Taste is moderate sweet and very lightly bitter. After taste of roasted malt and fruit. Alcohol hidden well. Bloody fantastic!!
(From notes 17.11.12) Tap. Smooth beer, excellent flavor. Slight alcohol noticeable. I have had this on bottle several times before, but it looks like my first notes were of the tap version.

Bottle at Deliruim Cafe, Brussels. Reserva 2009. Aroma is chocolate and malty, malty, malty! Touch of liquorice and maybe some coffee notes too. Appearance is a sexy black velvet colour and consistency, brown around the edges. Nice tan head, very fine bubbles/foam. Taste is liquorice, chocolate, beautifully laered, touch of coffee, slightly acidic and bitey really, maybe some brett notes? Good! Palate is placid, thick like a molasses beer, almost chewy, awesome! Overall, AWESOME! This fishermans beer had a dark and stormy rave in my mouth!

Bottle, 2009 vintage. Pours cloudy deep hazel brown with a creamy medium beige head that dissipates with decent lacing. Aroma is fairly light, with notes of caramel, molasses, raisin, dried fruit and a touch of coriander. Taste is light to medium sweet, and lightly bitter with a light warming finish. Medium body and velvety in the mouth. A light woody astringence. Not quite up to the original, IMO.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2012 Dark ale with a small head. Sherry, porto, cherry brandy,candy sugar,  figs and dates nose. Full body, ligh carbon, oily texture. All types dried ang candy fruits. hints of liquorica on palate. Sweet and coffee bitter aftertaste. Impresionante cerveza. Con alta presencia de alcohol con los primeros sorbos. Después sus aromas a especias, como pimienta te envuelve el paladar y a medida que vas avanzando captas nuevos sabores a café y azúcares. Toda una experiencia.

Dark brown body with foamy tan head. Lots of toffee, bit of cappuccino, candy sugar and rye bread. Delicate but not as rich as expected. Taste is nicer, bitter chocolate, roasted tones. Long, sticky finish. Very nice, smooth quad. Not cheap tough. (33cl bottle, from De Bierwinkel Leiden)

Incredible scotch aroma with a great amber pour, strong taste but subtle mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

bottiglia 2007,marrone scuro, schiuma tenue, al naso frutta rossa, caramello, in bocca prugna, ancora caramello, estremamente equilibrata, facile da bere nonostante la complessità ed i gradi, eccellente.
Aroma is surprisingly light. Taste is plums with a hint of alcohol. A bit of carbonation. No real noticeable hops. 2009 bottle

A 2009-es verziót kóstolhattam, a csakajosor.hu vezetőinek jóvoltából!
Csoda ez az ital, aminek már a színe is igen különleges, egészen sötét barnás, kissé lilás beütéssel, ami csillog a fényben és üledék szemcsék búvárkodnak benne és a tetejét egy piszkos hatású, öreg csont színű hab takar be. Illata és íze is igen sokrétű és bonyolult. Tele van aszalt gyümölcsökkel, mazsolával, kakaóbabbal, kávéval. Bőségesen van benne vanília, karamell, maláta, melasz, pipadohány és pörkölt tölgyfás aromák. A vége keserédes és száraz, komplex. Egyszerűen csak ül az ember, kóstolgatja, nyalogatja és nem tud betelni vele, mert mindig talál benne valami újat. Le a kalappal!

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2015 Pannepot Reserva 2010 - Color : Dark black beer and purple/brown reflection with no carbonation and small brown dense foam. Smell : chocolate, great sugar complexity, caramel, and roasted malt. Taste : candy, caramel and sugar with sour sensation. Aftertaste:  malt and caramel good complexity on palate. Very amazing beer !!!

Bottled [2009]. Pours dark brown with a medium sized beige head, fair clacing. Nose of burned malt, dried, dark fruits, vanilla and wood. Sweet flavour with caramel, dark malt, spices and dark fruits. Medium to full bodied, oily texture and soft CO2. As always a nice one from Struise.

Bottle. Vintage 2009.The second time I´ve tasted a barrel aged version, and I don´t think it does the beer any good, still a nice one though. Dark brown with brown head. ARoma dried fruits, raisins prunes. Taste dried fruits, some licorice (less noteable than in the ordinary version). Give me the ordinary Pannepot.

06 bottle. From reading more recent reviews it seems like this has chilled, mellowed, and maybe lost some of the bite. It is a subtle complex and tasty brew though. Fig, raisin, molasses aromas. All come through pretty significantly in the flavor along with a touch of wood and vanilla. No alcohol at all here. A bit of a gritty cocoa texture and dark cherry working later in the sip. There is a lot going on here and all melding together in a nice cohesive palate. Very tasty.

THOUGHTS: Much like the original but with wood. And maybe a little too much wood. A bit too tannic.
TECHNICAL: 2009 Bottle. Poured a dark brown that was nearly black in the glass with amber highlights. Another way to describe it might be mahogany. The aroma had moderate to heavy molasses and caramel; slight milk chocolate; moderate to heavy spicy yeast; grape; raisin, prune; apple; cherry; red wine; port; wood; oak; toffee; honey; brown sugar; maple syrup; alcohol; and tons of different dark fruit. The initial flavor was moderately sweet, slightly acidic and ever so slightly sour; while the finish was heavily sweet and lightly acidic with a long duration. There was caramel, molasses, maple syrup, brown sugar, prune, spices, yeast, cherry, raisin, wood, cherry pits, alcohol, vanilla, and slight chocolate and licorice when it became very warm. The medium to full body was oily and a little gritty with fairly soft carbonation and a woody, lightly astringent, lightly aloholic and slightly chalky finish.

Thanks Huhzubendah 

2009 Vintage

Pours a dark amber color with a thin cocoa head.  Aroma is raisin, fig, other dark fruit, some alcohol.  Sublime after 3 years.  Taste follows the nose, with toffee and caramel added to the mix.  Feel is full, with a nice malty aftertaste.  Overall, this is an outstanding beer...  One I'll definitely have again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPad

2009 bottle. Big beige head after first poured. Dark body. Aroma of chocolate and roasted malt. Taste is very deep in raisins, plums, caramel, bakers chocolate, and a bitter end to balance it. Very complex.

Aroma: A smell of raisins, figs, dates, almonds and Sherry.Appearance: A chestnut brown clear brew, an off-white small head, little lacing but good curtains.Taste: Tasting of brown sugar,  dark dried fruits and Sherry and Marzipan.Palate: Little carbonation, soft and sticky, a good body, a light dry finish.Overall: This one had not peeked, better than its two years older sibling. A very good sweet dessert beer.Note: Bottle 330 ml, on sale at Monks Wallingatan (Vintage 2007). Reviewed 2012-09-11.

Found a bottle at Bierkraft in Brooklyn. Pours a dark cola brown with a small head. Dark fruit, allspice, and cloves... a bit of alcohol burn, but nowhere near suggesting 10%. Some chocolate and muscovado, with just a touch of oak. Velvety smooth. Wish I could drink this every night.

Un nez de pruneaux séchés, de raisins, de cassonade qui se transmet intégralement en saveurs. Un tannin végétal presque métallique me dérange les premières gorgées, mais sestompe rapidement pour laisser place à un corps charnu mais délicat. Des courants de chocolats et de mélasse se pointent également. Une bête docile mais succulente.

Poured from a 33 cl bottle, vintage 2009.  Pours a dark red with a quickly collapsing tan head.  Bread dough, caramel and raisins in the aroma. Dark fruits and candy sugar in the taste.  A very nicely put together beer.

12 oz bottle. Pours a deep and dark burgandy brown with thick beige head and lacing. Aromas are oak, red wine, toast, belgian candy sugar, dark fruit guts, and honey. Taste is oaky wood, sour apple, figs, red vino, raisin bread toast, nuts and sweet caramel. Body was medium with a good bit of carbonation. Very complex and layered belgian beer. Wonderful.

On 33 cl bottle . 2009 vintage, bb16/08/2016.
Farm brown color, ok foam. Malty aromas, some dried fruits- Nice yeast influence. Also aromas of licorice and slight Caramel notes.
Full body & high complexity.
Some sweetness- but power of complexity gives good balance.
Very enjoyable

Struise Pannepot Reserva 2009. Poured lightly chilled into a tulip glass 8/26/2012.

Pours a very dark brown. Very little light coming through. Great head, lasts a minute or two. 

Great smell, but not very aromatic initially. Smells of sugar and raisins so far.

Initial feel is a medium thickness. Very smooth. Almost non-existent alcohol feel. Incredible for a 10%. Nice carbonation.

Taste is complex. Picks up where the smell left off and enhances it, makes it more full. The sweetness of the beer cuts most of the bitterness. A little dry, but nicely so. More of the raisin taste, but its being overpowered by what I believe is figs. Almost a smokey taste. 

Afterthoughts: Beer disappeared quickly, as I was trying to distinguish the flavors. I wish I could be more helpful describing the taste, however, they were too well mixed and nothing stood out but the ones I mentioned (sugar, raisins/figs). Beautiful lacing; very fine. Not quite as heavy as other quads, but its most likely the best Ive tried. 

Next time, might try with a snifter to bring out the aroma more.

Aroma: 9 - Beautiful aroma, despite the faintness. (Could have just been me, as well.
Appearance: 4 - Wish the head had lasted longer, but the lacing was magical.
Taste: 10 - Complex and yet, refined.
Palate: 5 - Soft. Subtle.
Overall: 20 - I loved it. Going back to buy the rest of the stock.

Bottle at home - 24/07/12 (2009 reserva). 
Pours dark brown in colour with reddish hues and a very thin tan head that settles quickly into a film atop the glass.
Dark fruits, red wine, oak, booze, and some spice on the nose.
Taste similar to nose, figs, prunes, plums more spice, decent level of booze but well balanced. 
Medium to full bodied with a creamy feel and a well balanced alcohol finish.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Brown with a beige head. A superb body. Aroma of belgian candi sugar, bread, toast, herbs, and wood. Quite similar to Chimay Blue but with a terrific woody touch from the oak aging that renders it superior.

11.2oz bottle, 2008 vintage. Thin light brown / khaki head. Dark brown color, lots of particles floating inside. Some ropes of lace. Chocolate nose. Light crisp carbonation. Unlike the De Dolle beers, this isnt too sharply carbonated to drink shortly after pouring, no need to let it sit... Although it should certainly be savored. Dry finish. Bigger body. Awesome, rich, super smooth aroma. Slightly vinous. Light wood. Light bitter taste, great sweetness. Light spiced taste. Light caramel note. Super tasty and delicious, really a great balance. Probably the best Belgian Ive had yet, I think. Super good. Awesome rich aftertaste. Finished my bottle easily, wish I had a lot more.

Poured into a snifter. 2008 vintage. Big thanks to SteveFinny for this.

3.5 A: Murky plum brown color. A good bit of sediment came out, much more than what would just be yeast. Short lived frothy beige head. Ill cut it some slack since its pretty old.

4.5 S: Great aroma on this. Tons of fruits, which are, in descending order - cherry, plum, more cherry, fig, date. Pleasant sugariness reminiscent of Pez candy. Plenty of caramel, candi sugar, and especially a "generic" spiciness. Light tobacco and raisin. This has an overarching earthy character, which I love in the Belgian quads. Lastly, oak to round things off.

4.0 T: The taste is also very good, but it lacks the power that the nose has. Oak is a bit more apparent in the taste. Otherwise, its quite similar to the nose, but with less sugariness and fruits and a bit more earth. Same fruits exist, just less force from each. Same tobacco and raisin. The Pez thing isnt found in the taste. More dirty earthiness exists though.

4.0 M: Lighter medium body. Good carbonation level, especially for this old. The carbonation could be a bit spritzier though, but overall its okay.

4.5 D: The taste was between a 4.0 and a 4.5 so Ill make up the difference here. Very good beer and probably the best variant. The Grand Reserva covers up too many flavors for me to prefer that.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-31-2012 20:43:56

Bottle 2008 Vintage thanks to TURDFERGUSON: Poured a mahogany brown with a sliver of tan head. Huge barrel aging aroma of alcohol, wood and sticky fruit. Taste is sweet malts, sticky fruit, not as prevalent alcohol and mellow woodsiness. This has been one of my huge wants for years and now that I have finally obtained it I wasnt disappointed in the least. Amazing beer!

Bottle, 2009. 
Dark brown with a tan head. Brown sugar, raisins, plum, vanilla, wood, coffee, and dark chocolate. Phenomenal. My favourite from De Struise!
Pours muddy dark brown with loh brown head. Aroma is dark fruits, brown sugar, dark malts. Flavor is dark fruits, brown sugar, alcohol and dark malts. Hint of syrup.
Pours muddy brown with a low tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, dark fruits and brown sugar. Flavor is roasted malts, dark fruits, brown sugar and alcohol. Quite nice.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2015 bottle at de kelk and struise shop ( both bruges) 
comparence :
i still like pannepot better.. this is smoother, something more complex as well, but the little bit in your face that the pannepot had is just gone.. if you like pannepot i would definetly recomend to try this one, but it just doesnt beat pannepot to me ..
the complexity is a little less than the special reserva, but wich is better? honoustley dont know. id say taste em all? and see for yourself :)
i gave them equal points cause to me theres not so much diffrence 4/5

rerate after drinking from draft @ bierhuyske - and more evolved tastebuds ? 
definetly big diffrense in smell ( woos, some wine) 
and taste ( that SUPERnice bordeaux taste . all perfect matching ( as always with struise) another delighted beer, and im glad to have tried it again . its way better than i remembered !

Bottle thanks to Thorpe429. You rock, Mike.

2009 vintage

The beer is chestnut brown with a thin beige collar. The aroma offers dark malts, brown sugar, raisins. Smells nice. Great flavor and remarkably easy to drink. Alcohol hidden very well. A tad sweet, with lingering notes of plums, figs. Another great beer from De Struise.
Dark brown colour. Aromas of plums. Taste is full bodied, oak and dark fruits.

2009 vintage - Pours deep dark brown pour with a nice foamy tan head. Nose is yeasty dark bread, with hints of cherries, apple brandy, oak, and a touch of tartness. A bit of metal on the first couple sips, but that goes away quickly. Taste is big bready malt, yeasty with some oaky, whiskey heat on the finish. Long finish is big dark bread, a hint of cherry and dark chocolate, and a bit of mellowed charred oak. Smooth, velvety carbonation makes for a nice creamy body.

2007 vintage, poured a dark brown. murky, mohogany with not much of a head that turned to No head pretty quickly. Not very much lacing left either. Got some of the expected smells of dark fruit, yeast, roast nut, candy sugar spice and a bit of funk. Tastes were a muted version of the smell the dark candied fruit and yeast were certainly present, along with a nuttiness and a bit of tart funk, which I did not expect. the feel was quite smooth but not as creamy as I remember it being in the past. Never the less I could drink this till I pass out. the Alc is not very present and the flavors are all wonderful, plus, in the end I think my bottle was not as good as others. Not sure what happened but know this beer is better than my experience this time around.
Smells of rye, Candi sugar, Belgian yeast, orange peel, pears. Tastes of Belgian yeast, malt, plums and brown sugars. Finishes sweet and thin; starts bittersweet.

I picked this up at a shop in Belgium. Gave a few to my friends. This is my last bottle so I should enjoy it before it goes to another friend. Enjoyed in a snifter and shared with RadarSock.

A - Poured light to dark brown into the glass. In the glass, dark brown with caramel amber edges. Half a finger leather head that fades to a small level of bubbles.

S - Caramel, brown sugar. Maple syrup and oak wood. some coffee or espresso as well. 

T - Taste is great. Up front, its pretty malty. Lots of burnt oak, caramel, cane syrup and apples. Finish is vanilla and syrup.  

M - 50/50 carbonation on mouth swish. medium body. Insanely dry finish.

O - Wow. Honestly. The Grand Reserva is much better than this one. Ive had the 05 and 07 Grand Reserva. This is the first standard reserva but its an 09 so maybe it needs more time? Its nice but Needs time? IDK.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2012 2009 vintage. Pours dark brown with black coffee hues, with a tan head that goes away and leaves some nice lacing. Aroma of wood, rubbing alcohol, fresh bread, slight cheese funk. Taste: oak, vanilla, bourbon, dark berries, bread, spicy hop finish.

Bottle. Pours a clear deep brownish plum with some sediment and a gray head that dissipates completely and quickly. Aroma has a nice note of far grain, candied sugar and dark fruits with a hint of alcohol and sweet fruits. Flavor begins with sweet notes of caramel, sweet grains and sweet fruit with spice and dark fruit coming out in the finish.

2009 vintage, purchased in Aarhus.  
Deep redish brown, bubbly head.  Hint of coffee yeast and malt in the nose, coffee, dark crystal malt, estery flavors.  Thick with crisp carbonation.  Nothing special, probably wouldnt buy this again.

33cl bottle poured into wine glass Vintage: 2009 (BB: 16/08/2016). Enjoyed next to Pannepot (2010) and Pannepot Grand Reserva (2005). Pours medium brown. Half (tan) fingernail head on gentle pour. Smells of sweet toffee, oak, and raisin. Hint of spice, but loads of woodiness here. Very nice! Taste includes soft balance of dark fruits and fig along with oak, toffee sweetness, and touch of spice. Warming booze rounds this one out, but the balance of oak and dark fruit is sublime. Of the three, this was my second favorite. The oak character adds a lot to this beer and I think it is very well balanced and smooth.

2008 bottle that I found at The Beer Mongers, out of all places. Brown in color, with a soft purple/red hue. Little bits of yeast chunks floating around in there, but thats only because Im rating the last 4 oz. that were in the bottle. Soft head sitting around the circumference of the glass, and on top of the beer, too. It looks fairly good. Lots of fig, and a soft plum aroma. The barrels provides a lovely oak and subtle vanilla aroma. The aroma further provides a raisin and grape aroma that are simply fantastic. Complimentary aromas are what makes this a strikingly pleasing beer to smell. Time has been good to this beer, carbonation wise. It still provides a soft carbonation, but its not to the level of being soda-like, which seems common amongst this still, when fresh. The flavor isnt as memorable as the aroma. The oak and vanilla play well with one another. Then a, somewhat, lasting grape, fig, and raisin aroma hover on my taste buds. I was looking for this to make more of an impression, flavor wise, but it just didnt seem to peak. Still, a wonderfully delicious beer, worthy of the praise. Plus, at the $7.50 price tag, I cant say that you could find a better deal anywhere else. Purchased months ago.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2013 Wow. Just...wow. It was just as exquisite as Id hoped, which almost never happens. Tasted from 11.2oz bottle into tulip glass. It poured an opaque dark reddish brown color with tan head of tiny bubbles, moderate thickness, somewhat lasting, with lots of Belgian lace. Perfumey aromas of caramelly malts, brown sugar, molasses, plum wine/slivovitz, hardwood, hardwood, smooth alcohol, black pepper, spicy Saaz-like hops. Belgian yeast characteristics, of course, but not overwhelmingly so: more like Chimay than Unibroue. More clove as it warmed. Malty sweet flavor, nice tangy hops balance, toffee, nuts, bread, toast, fruitcake, prunes, hints of coffee and cocoa. Slight, pleasant oxidation. Surprisingly light-medium body, well attenuated, with medium carbonation, less than many famous Belgian ales. Like a boosier, French oak barrel aged version of Abbey Dubbel style. What could be better? Bewilderingly well-crafted and delicious.
old fishermans ale aged on oak anno 2009. birra in pieno stile old ale con note legnose e leggermente torbate.

2009 Vintage, bottle got in a trade, thanks Adam! Deep mahogany brown in my tulip glass. Somehow still had a thin layer of tan head. Every showed great retention. Nose is oak, malt and light chocolate. Great flavors subtle and complex. Figs, vanilla, notes of oak throughout the sip and sugar type molasses in the finish. Mild spices also detectable. Finish is real dry. ABV is nowhere to be found. Nicely balanced. On the fuller side of medium body. Quite nice.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2013 
33 cl bottle vintage 2007 @ home. Rated on 25.10.2009
Aroma has some sour cherries and oaky notes. Flavour is sourish with cherries, oaky notes, chocolate and spices. The barrell has made Pannepot more round  this one does not have sharp edges to run into.
8-4-7-4-16=3.9

33 cl bottle vintage 2007 @ home, BBE 03/2014
Aroma has funky and oaky notes with dark fruits and hints of cocoa. Flavour has oaky notes, some slight sourness, dark fruits, some spicy notes. Finishes with sweetish licorice and a feeling of alcohol. Round, smooth and delicious.
8+4+9+4+17=4.2
2008 @cbc: Little head, dark brown. Nose is sweet raisin, cake and prune. Semifullbody and long. Taste is mature prune and raisins with a ballancing hoppiness.

Pours black, light tan head, thin collar.  Nose is dark fruit, chocolate, oak, booze.  Taste is more of the same with a higher booze influence and some clove and molasses.  Medium to full body, creamy finish, rich.

Bottle from Struise Webshop. Pours chestnut brown with a small, sticky of white head. Nose is sweet and candy like. Loads of cloves, banana, spice, vanilla and mild earthiness mingling with dark and dried fruits. Very sweet. Behind is a heap of spice and vanilla in the taste with massive christmas cake - especially plum, front up. Medium palate with sweet bitterness at the finish. nice, and a quaffer despite the abv

Poured from an 11.2 ounce bottle into a chalice, 2008 vintage.

A: Murky thick dark brown body with almost no head on top, just a thin tan ring.

S: This is very complex and strong. Oak, brown sugar, figs, chocolate and some mild alcohol. Its hard to put a finger on the aroma and I expect more will appear as it sits more and I sip more.

T: Candied and brown sugar make up the intro into a grape and fig wine-like mid-taste that is accented by mild oak, chocolate and caramel. Wow. The finish has some oak on it with a touch of alcohol and a cloves spice that gives a nice spicy finish. This is a fantastic beer!

M: Very thick, slightly syrupy, with very light carbonation.

O: I knew this was going to be good and Im glad I didnt pass it up. This is a very complex and well balanced beer that makes me want to sip very slowly to savor it.
Lots of wood, sweet molasses, spices, herbs, plums and generic dried fruit. Very complex.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2015 Bottle, 2009 vintage. Pours dark-medium brown, with dense, thick head that lasts a while. Aroma is like all the great Belgian ales in this style; sweet, malty, notes dried fruits. Taste is complex yet subtle, not overly sweet, with flavors of dates, vanilla, wood, spice, yeast, bread, alcohol, and just a bit of bitterness. Carbonation is soft and mouthfeel is sort of chewy and velvety. This is one of my favorite Belgian ales. Complex, yet subtle and balanced. Wonderful. Will try it again, and would like to age some of these. UPDATE: bottle, almost 3 years old. Lost complexity and depth, still good, but not a fan of aging these.

Tap, 2008 vintage.
Pours a deep tawny, with a thin head.
Spicy, mature aroma, malt, caramel, dried fruits, oak, walnuts, raisins.
Semi-sweet, full bodied, medium bitterness, creamy CO2.
Spicy, wine-like taste, malt, caramel, oak, candied sugar, raisins, plums, chocolate, coffee. Very complex, extremely well balanced. Ridiculously drinkable. (2012-05-11)

Tap @ CBC. 2008 vintage. Deep brown, ruddy red with a large tan head. The nose is sweet cherry liqueur, deep malty chocolate notes. Some strawberry and fruit leather. The taste is much the same, full bouncy strawberry malt base meets spiced cherry fruit chutney. Light vinous notes, some port wine and nuts. Great. Full bodied, a bit hot. The carbonation is active on the tongue. Overall, a beautiful beer. Glad I got to try this!

Bottle to oversized snifter (2009 vintage). Looks good; dark with low carbonation and thin lacing. Smells good too; malty and boozy with pleasant notes from the barreling. Tastes pretty good, but not spectacular. Kind of surprised, actually. I definitely expected more based on the reviews of others. Average on the palate. Overrated.

Quite a beer, quite a beer. Poured at a good temperature with a small to medium sized, tan, foamy head and no lace. Color is an opaque brown in the balloon part of the glass and in the narrrower part a hazy/cloudy amber orange red with some particulates and some tiny bubble trails. Aroma is malt, yeast, roast, fruit, red wine. Flavor is like nose, very nicely balanced, with bitter, sweet, and tang all pronounced, yet harmonious. Body is full, lush, mouth filling and carbonation is perfect. Finish is like flavor, tapers slowly, and has only a little alcohol warmth. Wonderful beer!

2009 Bottle. Pours a very muddy dark brown with a small tight tan head. Nose is sweet molasses, nuts, hints of fig and prunes, burnt sugars and oak. Flavor is follows suite of the nose and is medium full bodied with a sweet oaky finish. Very complex nose and flavor that has smoothed out well. Very tasty beer.
Bottle, pours dark amber. Aroma is bready and yeasty. The flavour is very smooth. Very easy to drink. Lots of spice, typical struise finish. This is yummy
Aroma is dark fruit with vinous notes and a strong hint of alcohol.  The flavor is dark fruit, nuttiness, caramel and a dryish, mildly tart/alcoholic finish.

Pours a dark brown almost black color with a paper thin head with great lacing for a quad. Aroma of caramel, figs and raisins. Tastes sweet and fruity, oak notes in the back. Thick and chewy yet easy to drink, not too boozy, the aging has done this beer some good

Bottle.  Caramel, apples, fruits, malts, toffee, candyish, brown sugar, a lot of pleasant smells going on.  The look is brown in color, slightly muddy, and has a beige colored head.  The taste is sugary, brown sugar, fruits, toffee, and caramel.

A - pours hazy cola brown with a golden tint. Low tan head that loudly fizzes  away. S - aromas of cola syrup, dark fruits on the nose. Notes of brown sugar, molasses and candied sugar. Hint of antiseptic. Oak notes as well. M - tangy vibrant carbed brew. T - tangy notes up front. Dark dried fruits and citrus notes up front. Candied sugars, molasses, roasted malts and antiseptic subtly metallic  on the palate. Drier lightly bitter mocha and coffee end. O - very good Belgian strong. Better than regular pannepot I reckon. 8

2008 bottle.  Opaque brown with particles and small beige head.  Aroma caramel and brown sugar, dark fruits, nuts.  Full bodied, dont really notice any alcohol.  Flavor is very briefly sweet which then gives way to a touch of wood and then a mostly bitter almost tannic finish.  In the background are cherry, coffee, chocolate, caramel, and spices like nutmeg.  Great stuff.

Finally getting to try this one. Bottle into snifter. 2009 vintage. Nose is rich caramel with some dark fruit and red berries. A lingering butterscotch note with some molasses also were detectable. I love those aromas. Dark brown body with a light tan head. Flavors of rich toffee and caramel with some more dark fruit, a touch of alcohol, cherries, molasses, and some earth and light chocolate. Another great Struise brew.

2008 Version // aged on Porto barrels // 15 cl. draft @ Delirium Hoppy Loft // dark rhubarb / wine gummies / raspberry with a tiny, vanishing tanned head // smells very sweet, wine gummies, gummy bears, sweet spices, caramel, very sweet read grapes // taste follows smell, wine gummies, gummy bears, sweet spices, caramel, very sweet read grapes, sweet malts, touch cake, figs, plums, very sweet porto, almost warming, drastically different from other version I have had & havent had a bottle of this one yet but I assume it will be very different as well, wine gummy beer // smooth, oily, soft carb, slides right down // damn fine beer, cheers for Struise

2009 bottle. Pours dark mahogany with reddish highlights, under a too-thin spotty beige head.  Very complex nose, with sweet earthy toffee, some molasses, figs, cherries, a touch of bakers chocolate...smells yummy.  Taste is pretty good, not as awesome as the nose, but still pretty swell to drink.  Starts malty sweet with some notes of figs, molasses, a little bit of dark funky cherry, some dusty yeast, mild earthy sweetness, mulling spice, a touch of oak, and finishing with a bit of toffee syrup.  Overall not a very strong body or mouthfeel, but the flavor is so full and round and complex it more than makes up for it.  Nice warming feeling after the swallow.

2008 bottle. Rich aroma of figs and raisins, caramel, spice, cherry, licorice. Very complex nose.  
Lovely, fine, bubbly head on dark brown beer with orange tints. Head doesnt quit.
Mellow, aged flavor, tangy fruits, dried fruits, wine or port, licorice, grapes, rye bread, molasses, more spices, alcohol, some minerals. Certainly complex and flavorful. Well balanced too. Peppery finish with moderate bitterness. Excellent stuff. Very smooth and oily body, though not too heavy.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2014 2008, 330 ml bottle via Beer Planet. Pours a dark brown with medium tan head. Aromas of chocolate, roasted malt, and a hint of vanilla. Flavors of caramel, dark chocolate, nuts, and spice. Creamy. Some lingering bitterness but over overall very well balance for 10%. A great beer.

2009 vintage. Pours dark mahogany with a reddish tinge. Toffee coloured head, which dissipates fairly quickly. Initially, this seemed to have a more obvious alcohol bit than the "regular" Pannepot, but as the beer warmed it mellowed considerably. Still, I must admit I found the spices and fruityness to have been masked by the oak.
UPDATED: OCT 29, 2016 dark brown black coloured body with a off white head a spicy roasted malty fruity aroma a spicy roasted malty fruity sweet caramel taste with a alcholic bitter finish

Bottle 330 ml [2009]. Appearance: Dark amber with a small quickly vanishing beige head. Aroma: Spices (cinnamon), fruits (raisin), carmel, malt, wood and vanilla. Taste: Spices, fruits, raisin, wood. Dry finish (wood?). Overall: Complex and well balanced. Very nice beer, but I prefer the regular one. Oak hide some spices.

(2008 vintage) 11.2 ounce bottle purchased fourteen months ago at Holiday Wine Cellar ($8.99).  Pours a dark brown-plum hue with a finger and a half of beige foam.  Aroma has lots of fragrant overripe fruit (cherries, prunes, figs) along with nutty caramel, port wine, molasses, and chocolate.  Flavor of thick toffee, sticky holiday fruitcake, rich chocolate, cherry, raisin, anise, cinnamon, and some dry oak.  Fairly sweet into the finish but not cloying.  Dry woody finish.  Full bodied with a thick and heavy mouthfeel.  High ABV is well hidden.  Expensive but an excellent beer and glad to have finally been able to get a bottle.  (610, 681)

33 cl bottle into a Struise glass at the Brugse Beertje.  Pretty black, good foamy head.  Lovely sweet and substantial aroma, inviting, lovely, light chocolate, waft of apricots.  A discrete and lovely beer.  Excellent and a delight to drink.

2008 Bottle; Pour is murky dark golden brown with a modest fine bubbled khaki head in this tulip; eventually hazing the glass, with some light lacing here. The nose is on the sweet and malty side; brown sugar, toffee, caramel, with some oak treatment. The flavor profile is very malt forward; more brown sugar, toffee and caramel, some molasses, dark fruit, like plums, earthy oak.... it has a light bitterness, nice mouthfeel.....I think i prefer the standard over this one.

08/02/2012 Bir&Fud Bottega (Vintage 2007). Magnifico colore bruno, denso, quasi impenetrabile, schiuma morbida color senape che crea magnifici contrasti di colore. Aroma intenso di botte, vaniglia, note di frutta secca e liquirizia. In bocca è liquorosa, dolce, con intense note di liquirizia, caramello, ciliegie e alcol. Perde un po di corpo rispetto alla Pannepot classica e risulta meno carbonata. Birra complessa e magnifica.

33cl bottle. Vintage 2007. Color is hazy and deep dark brown  with decent beige head. Aroma is raisin, malty, spicy. Taste is oaks, fruits, spices. ends with a little bit bitter alcohol. Very good beer.

2009 bottle very dark brown with a large tanned head. aroma is sweet, chocolate, raisin, dark brown sugar, some wine notes. taste is smooth and sweet with coffee and licorice. finish is complex, spicy, with restrained (coffee) bitterness. cherries, chocolate and oak are abundant. I prefer the standard pannepot, but this is still fantastic.

11.2oz bottle poured into a snifter. 2009 vintage. Pours dark brown with about a finger of khaki head. Aroma of caramel, dark fruit, vanilla and Belgian sugar. Taste is light sweet. Everything I said above with some oak and a little boozie warmth. Full bodied with a sticky texture. Lively carbonation and  a very long finish. Overall, I like this beer. I would love to find an older batch or age on of these for a few years.

Bottle from Beautiful Beers. Vintage 2009. Pours almost black with good head which lasts forever. Huge scent of chocolate malts, cherries and coffee. Taste of bitter chocolate, coffee, fruitcake, cherries, spices, oak and lovely sweetness. Massive beer. Complex and very serious. Westvleteren 12 beater? Perhaps.
2005 bottle.  Smoky body with a sweet apple wood body.  Raisins and plum.
UPDATED: MAR 16, 2013 Aroma avainillado, a pasas y regaliz. Color marrón oscuro. Sabor maltoso, a vainilla, madera, pasas.

Vintage 2009. Bottle at home. Pours a very hazy deep dark brown colour with a big, frothy and light brown head. Dried fruit in the nose along with, oak, leather, chocolate, and some perfumy alcohol. A wonderful and pleasant aroma. The flavour is also round and balanced with a bit sour woody touch. I also find the oak, dried fruit, raisins, and leather in the mouth, with hint of roast, and warm alcohol in the end. Oily mouthfeel with light bitterness. A real treat on a late and dark evening,

pour murky brown, with a very small off-white head.
Aroma is heavy of plums, prunes. Also vanilla, leather, oak, and Belgian yeast in here as well.
Taste is quite sweet, with a somewhat bitter aftertaste.
Medium and fizzy body, with a fizzy carb. as well.

33cl bottle, 2008 vintage.
Pours dark brown with an offwhite head.
Smells deliciously rich of red fruits, caramel, wood, alcohol, cinnamon, spices.
Tastes equally rich, with a strong sweetness, a dash of bitter, and an elegance of fruitiness with a nice slightly spicy alcohol finish.
The texture is creamy, body is medium to full, and carbonation is soft. I love this beer.

Bouteille de 33 cl. Arômes intenses de raisins bleus frais et de cerises confites. Caractère vineux assez présent. Robe bourgogne et limpide, peu de mousse et effervescence assez faible. En bouche, la bière montre un caractère fruité très intense, rappelant les raisins bleus, les pruneaux et les cerises noires. Le malt apporte des notes de caramel foncé. Le chêne demeure assez discret, apportant peut-être une délicate astringence en fin de bouche. Finale relativement sucrée montrant aussi une pointe dalcool. Une bière dessert à siroter tranquillement.

Rating #691, flaske fra Toft Vin  

En øl jeg længe har set frem til at smage, men aldrig har fået købt. Fredag aften skulle være den store aften, og jeg fik den smagt, men noterne gik tabt. Jeg prøver at vurdere den her, ud fra hukommelsen: Pannepot Reserva ligner ikke noget usædvanligt. Vi taler om en meget mørkebrun øl, med et meget middelmådigt skum. Duften understreger kvaliteten, men ikke så mange detaljer som jeg havde håbet på. Der er ubestemmeligt krydderi, træ(!) og alkohol. Måske en smule karamel eller sukker. Smagen er en anelse sødere og især blommer  og brun faring / karamel træder tydeligt igennem, i mindre grad sammen med træ og krydderier samt humle. En del alkohol og bitterhed, som er godt balanceret med resten af øllen. Der er desværre også en smule metal til stede. En god tyngde og tykkelse i denne øl. Jeg husker desværre ikke min samlede konklusion.
Dark brown with golden head. Aroma is dark fruit, booze, sweet caramel, candi sugar. Taste equally sweet and boozy, with lots of fruit. Bit of toffee too. Pretty nice and pretty full on.

2009 vintage. 11.2 oz. bottle, pours a murky dark reddish brown with a small beige head. Aroma of oak, dark fruits, vanilla, brandy, caramel / toffee, molasses and some Belgian yeast. Flavour is beautifully vinous, with notes of plum, raisin, oak, caramel / toffee and Belgian yeast - a concatenation of flavours. Everything works well together - tons of depth. Finishes quite sweet and oaky. Classic Belgian Strong Ale.

Thanks to Holy for the bottle.  Dark brown pour, the head increased initially after the pour finished and a bit remained for a while.  A warm, pleasant, spicy aroma; reminds me of root beer without being cloying, and I believe I can even smell the oak.   Lots of flavor, starting with a cool sweet malt with raisins and figs, and turning into a woody oak (fortunately without splinters).  Very nice.

On tap at the excellent Struise beer shop in Brugge, Belgium (last Christmas). A dark brown coloured pour with a healthy beige head on top. Typically sweet, Belgian yeasty aroma. Tastes sweet, fruity, caramel, vanilla, spice, malty. Incredibly rich, warming and complex yet surprisingly smooth and easy to drink. An elegant Belgian masterpiece. Beautiful.
2009- pours a deep brown with off white head with almost not retention or lacing. Nose and taste are of spice, fig, raisin, malt. Very well rounded and balance beer. Very happy to get to try this.

33cl bottle 2009. Very dark brown with beautiful tanned but very small head. Nose : roasted malt with strong wood rasin aromas. Dried fruits and some herbal notes. Some little banana ester aromas. Cheese. Sip : Sweet with deep complex transition into bitter and dry like coffee beens. Another great desert like treatment from De Struise.

Im not a big fan of the style but this has a nice oaky, slightly tannic edge to the sweetness that makes it a bit interesting.  Still not something Id die for, but a very solidly made beer regardless.

Very dark brown, tan head. Nose is sweet, roasty, malty, with hints of oak, coffee, liquorice and plums. Taste is close to the nose, but with the sweetness and roastiness more pronounced. Somewhat oily palate, smooth carbonation. Complex and satisfying.

2009 Bottle
Appearance - Brown body, silky lacing
Aroma - Yeast, toffee, brown sugar, honey, oak
Taste - Figs, raisins, honey, molasses, wood, alcohol

This beer is incredible, especially the way layers of delicate flavors settle in. The finish is so smooth, and with a sweet/sticky alcohol finish it is sure to please.

0,33 l bottle, Dranken Geers, Oostakker.
Poured brown with a creamy tan head. Aroma of caramel and wild fruits, molasses and wood, cocoa and rosehip, raisins. Molasses and raisins, cocoa and candy sugar with a woody background, roasted grains. Very complex

Clear dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, dried fruit and yeasty. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet finish. with a little warming alcohol. Extremely smooth, soft and full bodied. Hides the ABV very well. 050212

This Pannepot beers are just one reason why I love quads. A: Well I must say this looks alot like a soda maybe cherry coke?  With a small white head. S: Dark cherries, cinnamon, oak, and some dark dried fruits, this one is complex. T: Starts of with some dark fruits, cinnamon and oak but moves on to more candi sugars with peppermint spice and a caramel malt finish. M: The mouthfell was more creamy then expected, very nice. O: A complex beer here, that was damn good, the oak barrels change the beer where there is no alcohol anymore and the spices are more upfront then in the regular pannepot. However I enjoyed the regular pannepot more but all of them are damn good.

Top 1%?  4.14 rating?  For this stuff?  Am I missing something here?  It is a nicely balanced Belgian ale, with flavors of brown sugar, oak, coffee, and cola, and a bland aroma.  This reserva is not in the same league as regular Pannepot - but apparently it is a barrel-aged version of that beer, so maybe something wasnt right here.  A pretty average abbey ale, imo.  I would like to try it again, but at $13 a bottle, I probably wont be picking up more any time soon.  Another tip of the hat to Adrian!  (2008 bottle)
2008 bottle.  Amber pour. Very strong  aroma of spicy dried fruit.  This would go great with a nice fruitcake.  Taste is sweet, oaky, and vinous.
2007 edition. Aroma of old and wet wood, candy, chocolate and roasted coffee. Taste of old wood, chocolate, coffee. Warm alcohol finish.

2009 bottle. Pours a dark brown color with red hues and a thick fizzy cola head. Nose is oak, raisins, dark figs, cherries, and a dark sticky malt note. Palate is thick and chewy, light cola fizz, lots of sticky palate residue on the tongue and molars. Flavors of cherries, light alcohol, grapes, hints of wood
Dark red-brown, almost purple. Smells like pie spices, vanilla, and stone fruit. Taste gets banana involved on top of the fruit, but the feeling is just the greatest. Smooth, full, and creamy.

Amazing! Auction win.

What  I loved so much was the appealing oak, chocolate and dark fruit aroma. It really smelled good.

But what I loved even more, was the caramel, moleasses, fruit, spice, bread and oak flavors that were blended to near perfection. This is a must for all beer lovers.
