2009 bottle pours deep dark ruby with decent clarity and a perfect quarter inch ivory head.  Aroma is raisin, plum, hints of tartness, marshmallow, very subtle aroma.  Taste is mildly candy tart caramel, hint of vanilla, plum, some lingering spice, brown sugar, peaches, a hint of chocolate.  Body is velvety smooth, syrupy sweet but with a balanced juicy spicy finish.  Overall, just awesome.
2008 thanks to Elwood. Belgian quad like flavors with raisin and fruit. Very nice.

Bottle. Pours deep, nutty brown with frothy, light beige head; good retention and spare lacing. Aroma is dark fruit, brown sugar, cookie malt, and toasted nuts. Flavor is sweet malt, dark fruit, oak, faint earthy hops. Full body, medium carbonation, and high warmth.

Bottle.  Pours clear dark brown with a medium, creamy tan head, medium retention with light lacing.  Aroma is heavy cookie and caramel malt, light alcohol, dates, figs, earthy hops and oak notes.  Flavor is malt dominant with oak, alcohol and dates, figs, and medium bitterness with a sweet finish.  Full body, high warmth and medium carbonation.

2009 bottle. Deep brown body with mahogany highlights. Frothy, beige head that quickly reduces to pools. Sweet, fruity aroma with notes of overripe plums, raisins, sugar, Band Aid. The flavor is moderately to heavily sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes moderately sweet and moderately bitter  just enough bitterness to keep the sweet malts from becoming cloying. Basement mustiness and Band Aid plastic taste, but lots more overripe dark fruitiness. Medium to full body, watery texture and lively carbonation.

2008 Vintage bottle courtesy of a trade with Rasmus40.  Pours a dark brown that does not allow light to pass through with a thin cream colored head that lasted through the first two sips and left light lace. Very pleasant aroma of raisins, dates, and oak.  The flavor is malt with a touch of earthiness to it and some moderate oak.  Some mild dates present as well. Mild alcohol at the finish but definitely present.  Nice beer, but like the previous rater, I think I prefer the original slightly more.

Dark amber/brown color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, yeast, some oak, caramel, dark fruit, & spice; Flavor of roasted sweet malt, yeast, oak, caramel/toffee, dark fruit (notably plums & grapes), raisons, spice, and some bittersweet chocolate; Finish is dry; Nicely balanced & complex; Overall, very good brew - though, I think I still prefer the standard one.
[Rated 06/06/2010] Pours caramel dark with tan head. Taste is similar to the non-reserva version, but flavors are a little muted. It has the same nice nutty flavor and is overall very good.

this was the 09.  Pours dark brown with a medium tan head.  Head is creamy and dense and somewhat lasting.  Nose is heavier dark dried fruits, vanilla, sweet malts and some woody notes.  Flavor is plums, raisins, woody barrel notes, vanilla, subtle sherry like oxidation.  Sweet throughout and almost just a touch of tartness if you really hunt for it. also some nutty flavors come out.  Mouthfeel is creamy and moderately heavy.  Alcohol burn heat is there.This one isnt bad at all but quite underwhelming considering the score.

2009 bottle served in a Trappist glass.  Chocolate brown pour with a short lived beige head.  Brown sugar, Sherry wine, and cherries in the nose.  Much hoppier Thani expected.  First taste is hop leaves on top of medium dark roast.  The flavors seem a little muted in this bottle and I do get a hint of oxidation at the end.  My fear was that this had aged too long before I bought it.  Its got good "bones" but you can tell something is missing.  Medium body.  Slightly sweet and alcoholic at the end.
Strong, oaky, malty, full bodied but a tad boozy (10% abv). Little head (1/4 in. approx.) that disappears quickly.

Bottle.... from trip to Antwerp...It pours dark brown with a creamy large tan head.... the aroma is fruit, spice and loads of caramel..... the flavor is fruity, grapes, spicy, prune and loaded with caramel flavor.... nice complex.... very Belgian....

As close as I have come to a perfect rating with the only marks off for a little underwhelming aroma, the taste is remarkable but lacking in a little roastiness that I was expecting, but as smooth a belgian ale as Ive ever had. A wonderful beer that I was very proud to share with friends.

33 cl bottle @ home.
Originally rated on 20100323.
Rich in aroma and flavour, a very complex brew.

2008 bottle.  Pours deep brown, opaque, with thin, quickly fading head.  Nose presents strong oak, caramel, chocolate molasses, dark honey and fruits.  Flavor is not as complex, spicy dark malts, light caramel and oak, some bitter chocolate, an alcohol bite at the end.  Palate is medium, but wish it were a bit fuller.  Still, overall very tasty and always a nice treat.

09 vintage.  Dark brown pour with a small beige head.  Faded to a quick collar.  Aroma was dark candi sugar, light bubblegum, some grape and some heat.  Flavors were full of rich candi sugar, grapes, figs, super light roast and some booze.  Mouthfeel was full with moderate carbonation.  Nice and fitting.  Didnt get much, if anything from the oak on this one.  Good but not much different than the regular offering...

Bottle. In celebration of my 300th rate. Thanx Benh ;). Pours murky brown like muddy water. Thin cream head. Very feint oak aroma peering through the Belgian candy. Dried fruis and candy on the flavour. Raisins. Great mouthfeel. Thick. The sweetness rearsits head at the finish but doesnt linger. Thoroughly delicious. The alcohol is disguised but leaves a nice warmth. Bring on the next 300.
Cracked bottle celebrate 370th rate..... Murky brown with little head. Candi sugar aroma. Sugary taste, Belgian yeast. Very sweet. Couldnae say its fucking shite

2009 bottle into Trappist glass. Pours deep ruby-brown, small off-white head. Aroma is raisins, wood, vanilla. Taste is rich; dark fruits, raisins, brown sugar, spicy, also some darker roast/coffee/chocolate in there as well. Finish is bitter alcohol, a little medicinal. Mouthfeel is creamy and lively all at the same time. A delicious beer, what a treat; would live to try some different ages side by side.
Aroma of raisins, clove, and slight cocoa.  Pours hazy dark brown with a filmy blanket of head.  Tastes of allspice, clove, anis and dark fruits.  Smooth and dark.  Delicious.

2008 Vintage bottle purchased at øL in Walnut Creek, CA.  The aroma has some salty and mild anise hints.  Kind of floral and light molasses is also present in the nose.  Perhaps some cherry, too.  Dark, mildly hazy cola-colored body with a medium, strong mocha head.  Very nice.  Starts a little metallic with some mild mineral flavors.  Becomes a little fruity, roasty, and chocolate-like in the middle.  Quite robust.  Nice thick body.  This drinks well, but the barrel character is rather subdued and difficult to notice.

2008 bottle poured into a tulip glass. Pours a dark brown, almost black color with a small tan head. Lacing all around the glass and on top. This is a very special beer, the best Belgian beer Ive had to date. The nose is sweet, dark fruit, syrup, with oak. Taste is very similar, brown sugar, oak, fruit, spice. Fantastic beer!!

2007 bottle poured into a tulip.  Aroma of rich dark fruits and oak.  Mellow muted flavors in comparison to Pannepot.  Its very good but it almost seems watered down in comparison to the regular.  The aging didnt do this one any favors, but still a really tasty beer.

Date: December 3, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Binnys Description: Opaque dark brown with minimal head and limited lacing, aroma of oak, raisin, some spice and alcohol, taste was similar, smooth and medium bodied.  2009 vintage.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 Bottle - 2009 vintage. Thanks, Ryan! Muddy brown pour with a smaller off-white head. Aroma of brown sugar, raisin/fig, and yeast. Medium to heavier palate. Taste is yeast, oak, and sweet sugared candy. A bit of alcohol heat. Yummy.
33 cl bottle 2007 bottle. Subdued flavors from the regular pannepot. The oak aging adds a nice spicy note to it. Im a fan but the regulars great seductive flavors are muted here.

2008 vintage. Pours a three-finger light head that fades slowly leaving a good lace. Black color, no highlights, ton of yeast left in bottle. Medium carbonation and medium bodied. Dark fruit and alcohol nose and flavor is also alcohol and dark fruit, mellow sweetness. Expensive at $10.49 for a 330ml bottle from Julios Liquors Westborough, Ma.

Vitage 2006. Dark brown coloured beer with a medium brown head. Spicy woody and yeasty roasted alcohol hinted aroma. Full slight creamy palate. Finish is roasted bitter sweet with some wooden spicy yeasty and bitter alcoholic touches. Very good.

2009 bottle.  The pour is a very deep, garnet color with an average, frothy, beige head which settles to a lasting froth and leaves similar lace.  The nose is nice with chocolate cake, spiced cake, blueberries, red currant, figs, sliced almonds, wisps of alcohol, toasted caramel, light molasses, dry oak, and faint leather; very similar to the original.  The flavor is similar but subtly different; still fruity with blueberry and fig, dry oak initially, roast floating underneath, cinnamon, almonds and molasses still, chocolate cake and toasted caramel throughout, and leather and herbal notes moving into the finish.  The palate is lively, moderately full, velvety, and lightly coating; a little to fizzy but it works for this one.  The beer finishes fairly long with chocolate and roast throughout, light fig, and lingering herbal and toasted oak.  Very similar to the original with the same complexity, malt richness, and immense fruitiness, but a bit rounder and cleaner.  It seems much less young but the palate is lighter and more lively?  Still wonderful to drink and completely unique.

33cl bottle, 2008. Brown with a ruby hue, hazy with sediment, thin biege head. Raisin, alcohol, oak, prune, malt, brown sugar, yeast and some spices (cinnamon and cardamon). Low carbonation, somewhat sweet although the oak levels some of the sweetness out, prickly from the booze, a nice dryness, raisins and some other fruit as things develop. Becomes very dry and the end, some chardonnay notes, yeast and malt along with spices. Tasty, quite complex, just not sure I like it as much as the regular one.
Not quite as good as the standard Pannepot, which I found overrated.  A bit abrasive and a bit of an "off" taste.

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of caramel and milk chocolate, moderate to heavy hops of cooked orange, moderate broth for the yeast, with notes of raisin, brown sugar, alcohol bourbon, mild spice and sherry. Head is small, frothy, off-white with some slippery lacing and good legs and is almost fully diminishing. Color is hazy reddish brown. Flavor starts heavily sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes moderately sweet and lightly acidic and bitter. Palate is medium to full, creamy to syrupy in texture, with a soft carbonation and a moderately alcoholic and slightly chewy finish. Sweet and tangy and quite mouth-filling, this is an excellent sipping Belgian Strong Ale.

2008 bottle purchased in round brick liquor store in Santa Cruz this summer, then cellared. Pours deep auborn and brightly clear with plush beige persisant head, though tastes low carb. Faint candied-walnut aroma with madera and aged-scotch flavor, but watery and papery.

2008 bottle, November 2011.
Hazy dark brown, tan head.
Aroma: malty, earthy, candy.
Taste: licorice, candy, dried fruit, earthy, malty, port, warming, some chocolate, dry finish.
Full-bodied.
I liked the regular Pannepot more.

The aroma is fruit, raisin, vinous, oak, and earthy, more so than the regular Pannepot. Brown color, slight translucence, reddish hue, with a cream colored head.  The flavor is lovely, chocolate, raisins, other dark fruits, spices, oak.  The finish is VERY spicy, pine needles, taste of wood. Medium to medium/thick in body, creamy mouthfeel.  Unique beer.  Excellent.
Same comment as the pannepot. The taste is a little stronger on aroma. The difference is barely not noticeable.

Bottle @ Home, 2008 vintage. Pours very dark brown with a small fading tan head. Aroma of malt, caramel, oak, dark fruits, dates, figs, hints of chocolate. Taste is sweet malt, caramel, belgian yeast, lots of sweet dark fruit, dates, raisins, figs, oak, brown sugar. Medium body, low carbonation, alcohol very well hidden. In short a wonderfull beer. 301011

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2012 Nose is walnut, sweet, velvet, warm alcohol, hay, raisin, cranberries, feel is broad and very winelike, carb is mediumheavy, taste is port, sweet malt, cereal, alcohol, more ripe berries, sour earth

This poured a murky medium brown color with a small beige head. Aroma was lots of dark candy sugar, lots of dark fruits, some caramel, light oak, and vanilla too.  Flavor was alot more balanced than the regular pannepot I just had, maybe because of the oak, but probably because of the age difference in bottles. Great balance of roast, sweetness, spices, oak and chocolate. Really complex stuff.

Bottle @ Borefts Beer Festival. 2005 vintage. Tasted along with Pannepot Grand Reserva 2008. Pours dark chestnut with no head. Aroma is lovely dark fruits, figs, dates, caramel, nice yeasty notes, dark sugar, a hint of spice like cinnamon, orange peel, a hint of cocoa. Just very lovely. Taste has all the same qualities as the complex nose, but also adds a more evident barrel quality, oaky dryness and very vineous. It has an amazing balance and is really harmonious.

Bottle of a special bottling, courtesy of Mes and Sim at the Blind Tiger for Mikes 50th birthday extravaganza.  Pours a hazed murky ruby brown with a thin beige head.  Loads of wood, fruit, and sake yeast.  Light alcohol, spicy yeast.  Big and malty, spicy Belgian yeast.  Soft fruit, malt, a touch of earthy oxidization, chocolate, fruit, malt, and a bit of a resinous weed bitterness on the finish.

Big thanks to MesandSim for sharing an 05 bottle (keg for 6 years, bottled only last week!) Nose is very fruity, apricots, with a touch of citrusy hops raisins and caramel with overripe fruit and dryness. Some tannic notes. Lovely tart, lemony sourness with old fruit providing some maturity. Held up surprisingly well, some spice, dry and floral/ almost weedy notes. Very tasty.

(11.2oz bottle in trade).  Pours a dark mahogany color with think off-white head.  Aroma has some oak, caramel, and ripe fruits (grape?) along with some fantastic yeast.  Taste is sweet with more caramel, raisin and some candied sugar.  There is a little oxidation in this, but its not very distracting.  Medium bodied with a slick texture and so smooth finish.  Tastes like a quad.  Beautiful beer!

Bottle pours muddly dark brown color with off white head.  Aroma is awesome.  Ripe dark fruit, butterscotch, toffee, caramel, and a stickly sweetness that seems to linger.  This stuff smells so good I couldnt stop smelling it.  Just awesome.  Prickly carbonation and mouthfeel.  Flavors follow the nose.  Upfront has the caramel and toffee sweetness.  Its not cloying.  The middle has dark fruit notes, and it finishes with a alcoholic hot bite.  This was a great beer from start to finish.  Outstanding.

Bottle 2008.Pours copper with a small off-white head.Aroma of malt, biscuit, caramel, dried fruits and herbal hops.Flavor is sweet and warming with some green apples,caramel, alcohol and grassy hops.Full body,. soft carbonation.Really nice beer.

Bottle 330ml vintage 2008 @ Geokkjer
Pours cloudy dark brown with aoff-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel and dried fruits. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and light bitter with a kind of dry warm alcohol finish. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle for rating #3500: &nbsp 2005 750ml consumed in 2009. &nbsp Blacked brown, very dark, large foamy beige head, sticky lacing. &nbsp Sweet darkened malts on the nose, typical Belgian sweetness, some dark pitted fruit, figs and dates, even a little charred wood. &nbsp Soft tart dark pitted fruit on the tongue. &nbsp Sweetness has given way to a little puckering. &nbsp Still has a touch of sweetness. &nbsp A little prunish. &nbsp Oak is very soft, if at all. &nbsp Very faint wood aspect. &nbsp After 4 years this beer still has legs. &nbsp Lingering tartness amongst the prune, fig, date, and raisins. &nbsp Lingering tartness. &nbsp Still enjoyable, but waiting another year will make this one real unbalanced. &nbsp Good now, but a year ago I bet it was even better. &nbsp Still enjoyable.

Zeer troebel (bijna grijs-)bruin bier met kleine schuimkraag. Smaak overrijp fruit, beetje portachtig soms. Ook wat drop. Vol bier met stevige smaak, waarvan ik vermoed dat het alcoholpercentage hoger ligt dan de 10% die op de fles staat.

Bottle at volo.
Dark brown pour, big frothy brown head. Intense aromas of raisins, ripe dark fruit. Fruit cake, and red wine. Flavors are very fruity, and quite yeasty. Lots of plums, raisins, and quite a thick red wine finish, a touch of funk in the finish, this is aeging well, and adoptiong a touch of welcome funk, nice stuff!

Bottle from Summer secret Santa (ragesaq)  2008 vintage. Pours dark cola brown color with khaki head. Aromas of dark fruits, candi sugar, oak and Belgian yeast. Flavors of sweet raisins, plums, cherries, yeast and oak. Medium body with minimal carbonation. Very nice. Thanks Aaron!

2008 vintage. 11.2 oz bottle into a chimay goblet. I was able to get a very clean pour saving the last 2 ounces. I noticed a massive sediment ring along the bottom of the bottle. The last bit was swirled and poured into a snifter. That was very murky and musky.

A - Dark brown/rusty red body. Small off white head which resided to some edging. Moderate lacing.

S - Figs, candi sugar, caramel, yeast and spice. Faint vanilla. Some notes towards the end that are charred and woody, but rubbery and plasticy. Oddly enough it works. Really smooth and robust.

T - You sure as hell can taste the oak. Its a very strong oak flavor which is different from most barrel aged beers. Its very earthy. Vanilla, figs, candi sugar, Belgian yeast and a handful of spices. Some light metallic and medicinal flavors floating around. Really complex. Extremely smooth mouth feel and light carbonation makes it an easy drinking quad. Light alcohol flavors as it begins to warm up.

O - An interesting take on the old fishermans ale. Not sure how I feel about it compared to the standard pannepot. Its certainly different and unique. Its very delicious and the mouth feel is amazing. De Struisse can make some pretty amazing quads.

bottle on my daughters 3rd birthday - purchased at CBX last year.  pours a dark brown / light black with a perfect 1+ finger creamy white head - which eventually falls to a thin lacing.  big dark bruit aromas circle the nose with thin layers of oak and spice.  medium to full body with dates, plums, raisins, cherries, figs, apples, brown sugar, oak and a touch of spice.  very smooth with a twinge of alcohol.  dry finish with more dark fruits and light oak.  great beer!

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2011 Pours a very nice deep burgundy with beige bubbly head and no lacing .... aroma is of overripe fruits plums and some candi sugar ..... taste is of overripe fruits, plums, little candi sugar and earthy ... finishes dry and a little oaky .... mouthfeel is unreal smooth and little creamy with no trace of abv .... an awesome brew just a notch below the regular pannepot

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2011 Bottle of the 2006 at Kulminator. Dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma of brown sugar and raisins. Delicious caramel malty taste, brown sugar, molasses - sweet but not too sweet. Delicious!

Bottle of the 2008 vintage from the De Struise store in Bruges. Aroma of dark fruit, brown sugar and a hint of oak. Taste of caramel, malt, raisins, dates, plums, hint of oak and hops.

Bottle @ home. Deep brown appearance with a small tan head. Woody, caramel, toffee, dark candy sugar nose thats a lot more tame than the normal version. Somewhat spicy, caramelized candy sugar, toffee, dark malty, Belgian yeasty, woody flavor that again is tamer than the normal version. Interesting in its own right.

[3834-20110723] 330mL bottle. Toasted banana fruit malt aroma. Murky, dark mahogany brown body with a quick foamy tan head. Sweet and thick syrupy fruit malt flavour has a hint of a toasty charredness. Full body. Interesting. (7/3/7/3/13) 3.3
(w/ jerc; Vintage 2008, from Beer Planet, Brussels)

2011-07-23. Ruby tinged dark brown body, small beige head. Very fruity aroma, light alcohol. Flavour is similar, very fruity character, sweet sugary malt core. Hints at cherry like accents. Muted herbal spice touches in the finish. Oak is remarkably mild, with a modest bit of oak in the background, perhaps it has faded with time? Smooth medium bodied palate is very softly carbonated. Less complex than anticipated, but very nice. 2008 Vintage, Bottle from Belgium Trip

Bottle 2005  
Aroma  frontal fruity tartness , vanilla , grape ,dry alcohol , creamy malts, tad of spice , hint of spur cherry.
 Appearance  great pour , dark brown-black with med beige darker top. 4-
Flavor and Palate : medium bodied. Frontal tartness with sweet plum and raisin. Woody hints with darker malts behind. Bready malty base. Spicy finish.

2007 33cl bottle. Poured into my Westy chalice. Color is a dark brown with a huge off-white head. Crazy complex aroma of chocolates, sweet dark fruits, spices and caramel. Flavors are well blended of all of the above plus a bready maltiness. Sweet finish and a smooth mouthfeel, Not as potent as the Reserva but velly nice stuff....

Bottle shared by phaleslu. Thanks Peter.  Pours dark brown with a lingering  beige head.  Aroma is oak, plums, sweet and caramel malts. Flavor has a lot of oak, plums, sugar and malty. Has a dry finish with light carbonation. Overall a really good beer.

Rating #2600. 750 ml bottle, but I honestly cant remember the source. However, Id like to know because I dont think I expressed my sincere appreciation for a bottle this awesome. 2005 vintage, the first one- 3000 bottled in all. Pours a deep mahogany with a small beige head that manages to stick all the way down. Big oak on the aroma, along with notes of raisins, plums, brown sugar, earth, sweet and caramel malts, cranberries, some light funk, and a sneaky bit of booze that hits the nostrils late. Flavor of ripened plums, grapes, earth, candi sugar, dry grains, rain water, copper, and oak. Medium-bodied, with an initially fruity, then dry mouthfeel and modest carbonation. So complex, so nice. Amazing beer and the last piece of the Pannepot puzzle for me. What an incredible series. Id like to try them all in a single tasting sometime.

2008 bottle. Very dark brown body with a small white head. Strong aroma of blueberries, caramel, spices, chocolate and licorice. Great velvet palate with low carbonation. Sweet but not cloying, greatly balanced, chocolate and fruits. Excellent.
Outstanding dark strong ale just like the regular Pannepot, chocolate and licorice flavours nicely matured on oak.

330 ml bottle. 2008 version. BBE 08/2015.
Pours a dark brown colour without a head. Strong aroma of lovely oak, sweet berries and caramel. Lovely, smooth flavour of smooth caramel, strong stinging oak, sweet berries, caramel and some alcohol. Wine-like mouthfeel. Warming, oaky, fruity finish. Perfectly balanced. Just awesome.

330ml bottle from Bierkompass, shared
2008 vintage, BBE 08/2015- 
Pours dark brown with a small foamy head. Aroma has notes of raisins, oak and apples. Taste is heavy with caramel malts, raisin and notes of oaky apples. Fruity, smooth and spicy finish. Well balanced, tasty.
2007 bottled. Dark brown colour with a small head. Fruity aroma. Sweet taste with some caramel.

330 ml bottle. Very dark brown. Clear. Medium sized light beige head. Raisiny nose with hints of pepper and oak. Earthy sweet malty flavours. Quite a bit if caramel and dark sugars. Viscous maltiness. Surprisingly little oak detectable. Fairly low carbonation level.

330ml bottle poured a clear reddish brown with a small lingering tan head. Aromas of oak, vinous notes, toffee, light spice and light cherry. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of oak, toffee, grapes, cocoa and light spice with a smooth lingering fruity finish.
Fantastic dark brown color with a deep dark red glow coming through. I did find the original version just a little better, but this is still a very nice beer. Gonna try the Grand reserva real soon.
330 ml bottle a dark brown colored beer with a beige head aroma malts caramel dark fruits oak spicy and hops flavor sweet malts caramel dark fruits spicy hops and oak

Pours a nice mahogany hue with ruby highlights. Small tan head that leaves just a slight amount of lacing as it slowly dies down. A very bubble gummy aroma and dark dried fruit. Caramel and a slight vanilla aroma as well. Sweet taste with a nice overall flavor. Caramel, again in the taste. A little bitter in the back, mixed with a bit of a sweet aftertaste. Nice beer.

2007 bottle shared by badnewsbeers. Deep brown body, thin beige head. Nose of caramel, toffee, and sweet brown sugar. Body of toffee, toast, caramel, and alcohol; modest sweetness, finishing bitter with alcohol notes.

2008 Bottle - thanks spencerDB.  Pours a flat chocolate brown color with a small ring of beige head.  Aroma is soft barrel aging notes and vinous elements, lending itself to a sweet, yet tart aroma.  Hints of spices.  Flavor is smooth and well balanced; chocolate, barrel notes, earthy, raisons, and faint spices.  The different flavors come together seemlessly... Delicious.

Bottle 33 cl, Skjold Brune, Århus. Pours dark brown with a small tanned head leaving some lace. Lovely aroma of yeast, dark fruits, brown sugar, fidges, alcohol, malt and hops. Acidy sweet fullbodied mouthfeel. Velvety flavor of malts, fruits, sweet, alcohol, fidges, prunes and nice bitter tartness. All well balanced. Finishes sweet and slightly acidy in the beginning and with a great bitter tart aftertaste in the end.
2007. small bottle. ruddy brownish pour with minimal head. aroma of brown sugar, burnt lactose, toast and fig. flavor is similar and very sweet. maple syrup and raisin in the finish..

Had the Pannepot Reserva 2008 version at Brugse Beertje. Wont get any blacker than this. Aroma has caramel, roasted malts, coffee, licorice, charcoaled oak and some alcohol. The flavour is incredible. The dry bitterness of the coffee, with the smokeyness of the oak coming back sideways. This is really good and interesting, too bad I could only try one bottle.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2011 Had this bottle at Craig Garvies place. I absolutely love this beer. We had the 2005 oak aged version. The beer poured a deep rich ruby colour with lots of stewed fruits, cherries, Christmas cake, oak and creme caramel on the nose. The aroma is absolutely spectacular! Taste great with raisons and sour fruits balanced perfectly with the oak. Flemish red style but not quite so sharp. Very chewy mouthfeel.

Also on draught at the Boreft Beer Festival, 2011. Port wine barrel. Pours a brown colour with caramel, tar, leather and port wine characters. Lovely!

2005 vintage at a cgarvieuk tasting. Pour is opaque dark brown, with a small and inconsistent beige head. Nose is massively complex - sherry, raspberry, oak, stewed fruits... Taste is rich and funky, with plum fruit, raspberry, very juicy. The oak is present yet subtle. Slight hint of booze but in a rich, warming way, not unpleasant at all. Spices, figs, marzipan, hint of lambic sourness even. So many layers, yet it somehow stays silky smooth. Lovely stuff.

15 June 2011, bottle at my last cgarvieuk tasting! 2005 vintage. dark cherry, tiny bit of sediment, this is a faintly sour brown ale. some vinagrette, yeasty bread. lovely full body and faintly fizzy. sugary flemish brown. really nice and sweet. just fizzy enough. fermenting raisins. very lovely.

05 bottle I got in trade and brought to BA speedway release. Orange brown with big fizzy head. Yeasty suspension.  Nose apples and spice. Taste has a bit of cardboard for sure, but not too bad. Spice and malt and berry hints. Medicine back. Good but prob past its prime.

2008 bottle...pours an opaque chocolate brown with a medium sized tan head...nice retention and lacing.  Aroma is nutty and boozy...earthy...slightly sweet.  Flavor follows suit but is slightly more sweet...raisin...yet has subtle fruit and sour notes.  Not muddled at all.  Mouthfeel is silky smooth and the finish lingers with roasty notes and delicate hops.  Awesome!

Pours a dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is rasins, figs, oak, belgian yeasts, spices. Flavor is sweet caramel, belgian yeasts, figs, oak, well balanced, perfect amount of sweetness, dough, bread, candi sugars, wow this is wonderful.

33cl bottle @home, labeled Reserva 2008. BB 4/2015. Enjoyed as my 1000th rating.Shared with my better half. Poured brown color with a thin head. Complex aroma of molasses, caramel malt and dried fruits. Flavor is caramel, wood, sweet fruit and some spicy notes, everything blending together perfectly. Silky smooth, no trace of alcohol whatsoever. Long lingering caramelly finish. Medium bodied.

Fits in between the original Pannepot and the Pannepot grand reserva, taste wise. Great beer, but im not sure about the additional flavors that result from the aging on oak.. the port like hints blend in well, but theyre not my favorite.

330ml bottle, labelled PNP no. 4, 2008, nicely served at t Brugs Beertje. Low, beige head. Inviting deep, dark-ruby body colour. Fine smell of dried and dark fruits. Delicate taste profile with dark-dried fruits in interplay with candy sweetness, alcohol and a twist of barrel. Lingering finish and full bodied. Very tasty (Brugge, 02.05.2011).
Bottle from Klooster.  Pours slightly murky brown with off-white head.  Aroma is caramel, alcohol and cherry. Flavor is caramel, cherry, plums candy and alcohol. (Notes from offline rating)
330ml bottle shared with jb84 and kish84. burgundy with a tan head. dark fruit and aged belgian yeast nose. nice complex flavour. well integrated wood. nice sipper

Pour mahogany beige head and terrific lace. Aroma oak, sweet malt, spice, dark fruit. Taste oak, dark fruit, Belgian spice yeast, cherries, caramel. MF medium body mild carb. Good stuff tasty and well balanced abv well hidden.

330ml bottle from IPB. 2007 vintage. Best before March 2014.
Appearance : Deep brown with medium head that is short lived. No lacing.

Aroma : Spices with rich red fruits. Nice toffee and caramel with light alcohol. Light pears. Mineral notes. Notes of wood.

Taste : Red fruits with caramel and toffee. Nice spices with light hops and light mineral notes. Nice light sweetness on finish with notes of raisins and figs with spices. Some wood on the finish. Quite warm overall.

Overall : Nice stuff, quite complex. A bit too much alcohol. Appearance is also a bit disappointing. Nice wood presence, nice raisins and rich fruits. Very nice but the alcohol and light mineral notes didnt do it for me. Big belgians used to be my favourite thing but not that much anymore... palate changes I guess.

11.2oz bottle, 2008 edition. pours a dark, hazy, burgandy with a thick, rocky, off-white head leaving sticky rings of lace. aroma is fantastic with huge notes of toffee, brandied figs, raisin bread, and dark cherries backed by subtle notes of belgian yeast, cloves, dried pears, and cocoa with a hint of oak and vanilla as it warms. flavor is wonderful as well with big fruit notes of pear, red apple, black cherry, and figs all smothered in toffee and hints of brandy backed by rich, dark breads, winter spices, and smooth, lightly toasted oak. palate is rich, full bodied, and lightly carbonated with a lingering, fruity, sweet finish. overall, a world class belgian ale.
Bottle at Buckeye Beer Engine. Hazy brown pour with a thin beige head. Aroma of raisin, oak, banana and caramel. Caramel and raisin flavor with vanilla, oak and spice. Lasting sweet and boozy finish.

Beautiful clear brown with hints of red and a small tan head. Big aroma of toffee apples, cherries, dried fruits, apple juice and some alcohol that disturbs me a bit. Flavours are very smooth with caramel, oak, alcohol, grapes and almonds, but they are a bit thin. Ends rather dry but is smooth all the way, like pouring silk down the throat. If the flavours were a bit bolder and with less alcohol in the aroma, this would be an absolute top beer.
Beautiful Carmel aroma, thin head. Explosive smooth Carmel and malt aroma. Understated flavor, smooth and sour, some alcohol, nice, light bitter finish. Very good but not worth the price for me.

YUM YUM YUM YUM.  Treat to try this one.  Big caramel filled nose.  Spices, nuts, toffee, tender hints of chocolate, and Belgiany bread and malts take up the flavors on this.  The finish ends with a pleasant, yet light, dip into an oak filled barrel.  Damn good stuff.
Bottle. Pours dark cloudy brown with a medium off white head. Aroma is caramel and belgian spices. Flavor is brown sugar, caramel, and spices. Medium body and good heat.

Pours a hazy dark brown with a couple yeast floaties that sneaked their way in to party and a 2 finger, creamy beige head that fades to a thick skim after a couple of minutes and holds pretty well there for the rest of the glass leaving some lacing as I go. Aroma is dark fruit, dates, chocolate, light toast oak notes, a touch of alcohol, sweet bread spice, dark caramel, licorice and a little pine sap, not really in a hoppy way though. Flavor is big on dark fruit, chocolate, sweet white bread crust, dates, woody oak notes, sweet cherries, light fusel notes and dark caramel. Toward the finish comes earth and last years dry leaves. As it warms coffee and more dark fruit comes out along with slightly stronger fusel notes, no enough to be off putting, but they are somewhat noticeable. Palate is medium-heavy and creamy on the entry with an off dry finish and light, velvety carbonation. It never really feels too far toward any extreme in the range of mouthfeel description. Really good beer, one to savor and contemplate, but also one that would be dangerously easy to put down too many of at 10%. If you can afford to put down too many of a beer that costs $8 for a 330ml bottle, that is.

2008 bottle at Schraevenacker. It pours darkest brown, with a large, long-lasting beige head and fine carbonation. The nose is yeast, bread, pear, gooseberry, date, prune, fig, cherry, caramel and clove. The taste is full of sticky dark fruit: fig, plum, prune, date, raisin, blackcurrant and sultana. There is also brown sugar, caramel, milk chocolate, clove, wood and pleasant alcohol warmth, with a bitter-sweet finish. It is rich, impressively smooth and very well-balanced. Another gem from De Struise Brouwers.

2008 vintage.  Poured from 11oz bottle.  Pours dark brown with minimal head.  Nose is vinous with some dried fruits and toffee.  Taste is dried fruit some sweetness and just a touch of Belgian yeast in there.  The alcohol is well hidden.

33 cl bottle. Pours hazy mahogany/brown with a light brown head. The aroma is roasted malt, rock candy, raisins, plumes and is quite vinous. Flavour is sweet malt, caramel, oak, dark fruit and a hint of alcohol, lovely and complex.

2008 vintage.  Pour was a dark brown with a quickly decipating off white head.  Nose of toffee, fruit, raisins, and yeast.  Taste follows the nose and is sweet with a nice warming finish.  There is also a hint of wood from the aging process.  This is a phenomenal beer and certainly worth whatever it takes to get it.

This is the beer you work up to.  You start your quest, try different shit here and there, sign up for rate beer, rate a little, maybe do some trades, and then this ends up in your cup.  

And at that point you tell yourself it was all worth it.  This is such a delicious beer.  Read all the other reviews if you dont believe me.

330ml Bottle (2007 vintage) - Dark brown with a tan head. Vinous aroma with hints of Christmas pudding, dried fruit and spice. Warming and fruity taste with vinous fruits, Christmas pudding and marzipan. Complex, yet very easy to drink and enjoyable.

33cl 2008 bottle pours an almost opaque, deep, mahogany brown with a thin, creamy off white head.  Nose of brandy, caramel apples, booze, rum, nail polish, a little holiday spice, some tropical fruit, smells a little like a pineapple scented candle.  Flavor is lightly woody, a little nail polish, apples, malty, a little yeasty, pumpernickel bread, sherry, port, some light licorice.  Finish is full bodied, but smooth and lightly sweet, lightly woody.  This is so perfectly balanced right now.  The base beer has a ton of booze to it, but the barrel really adds and compliments instead of compounding the problem.  Theres alot of good beer aromas and flavors, but also plenty of unique barrel aromas and flavors and nothing is competing.  Its all very harmonious.
grapes, cinnamon, nutmeg, spices.  amber/ dark brown color with white head.  cinnamon, grapes, citrus, apples. low bodied
Sweeter than the regular pannepot. Sweet caramel and candy. Very tasty but not as good as the regular

Bottle, 2006 vintage. Very fine bubbles, head disappears quickly. Creaminess, vanilla, dark fruit in the nose. Very soft and balanced taste, butterscotch, caramel, vanilla. Medium to heavy body. Little carbonation, but far from flat. Nice and delicate long finish.

Vintage 2008 bottle Thanks to Sam. Pours out brown with some red highlights topped with a sand head. Aroma was of caramel, pit fruit, oak, and some spice. Taste was nice more of the pit fruit sweetness along with a good spice and malt.

pours black with tanish head. nose is malt syrup, old lady candies, liquorice, and spices. Not really what I was expecting at all. love that liquorice. taste is similar with a great lightness to it. you can drink these 9% beers like water. its crazy.
Muddy brown pour from bottle with a very thin head.  Aroma is dark fruits and light booze.  Taste is figs, raisins and yeast.  Smooth finish.  Excellent.

11.2oz bottle.  2008 vintage.  Served at cellar temp into a St. Bernardus goblet, leaving the lees in the bottle to enjoy later on their own.
Pours murky brown with a small short-lived light tan head that holds a wispy cap and leaves fair lacing.
Aroma is rich dark fruits, wine like tannin qualities, figs, plums, dates, raisins, candi sugar and belgian yeast, the oak and vanilla notes come through as well.  Quite complex and of very good strength.
Flavor follows suit with intense dark fruits as in the nose, candi sugar, caramel, molasses, chocolate, vanilla, oak, quite sweet, very very rich, minimal alcohol at the end.  Delicious.
Mouthfeel is medium-full, creamy, soft, low carbonation, somewhat sticky.
An absolutely fantastic BSDA.  Love the effects of oak aging to add an additional layer of complexity.  Quite a treat!

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 2007 bottle tasted blind as part of a top 10 quad blind tasting.

A: Deep brown body with the faintest hints of red.  Healthy khaki cap.

S: Plenty of dark fruits, figs and raisins.  A little clove and possibly nutmeg.

T: Spice (nutmeg?) and loads of dark fruits up front.  Nice malty base with caramel and brown sugar.

M: Medium-full bodied.  Smooth and velvety.

O: Very nice.  Layered and complex.  Top notch quad.

Beer is dark brown and hazy with a strong tan head of tiny bubbles that leaves a TON of lacing on the glass, its completely coated. Beer served in a Russian River tulip. Carbonation steady.

Aroma is sweet and caramelly with some dark fruit and candy in there.

Beer is sweet and medium to thick in the mouth. The roast comes up late and is separated from the total beer. This is a nice, caramel candied beer. Oddly dry late on the palate though. Beer is very drinkable. Its very awesome. If you like Quads, this is a must try. Low bitterness, easy finish, a great great beer.

The oak is not pronounced in oakiness or vanilla in this beer though, if it were more oaky in its nature I think I would appreciate the oak aging more. Personally.

Serving type: bottle

33cl bottle picked up from the web shop. 2008 vintage appropriately served in a De Struise glass... A dark hued copper with hints of amber, slightly see through, a little darker than Pannepot. The head is a light tan, only rises a couple fingers, not much especially for a De Struise glass pour. Good retention and lacing though... The aroma is surprisingly restrained for an oaked version of Pannepot, Pannepot seems to have stronger and sweeter quad notes. Typical quad notes of dark fruits, figs, and raisins are there but they come off a touch sterile, metallic, chemical. I dont get any nice caramel or candi sugar or oak. Sterile figs with alcohol. Im sadly not loving this... The taste is much better as it really brings out dried figs and raisins, subtle oak, and some molasses. Very tastey and drinkable. However, the mouthfeel is super light, especially compared to the base beer. Incredibly crushable 10%.

This is still a very good quad, just slightly disappointed in the nose and mouthfeel. I bought a dozen of these so hopefully they get better in time.

Bottle. 2008 vintage. Brown-mahogony beer with a thin light tan head. Spice and malt aroma with caramel, light sweetness, and light fruitiness. Malt and caramel flavor with light brown sugar, light spice, and light apple. Medium bodied. Malt and caramel lingers with light spice, light yeast, and light apple fruitiness.

2008 33cL bottle. Thanks Jason!  Classic luscious Pannepot, such a fantastic and wonderful beer. Its got everything you want in a Belgian Dark Strong and more, spice, caramel, and dark fruit. This version gains a drier edge from the barrel that meshes up with the spiced notes, although, the notable presence of wood is minimal. I love the multidimensionality of this beer, complex in so many directions. Fluffy, warm, refined, boozy. Digging a little deeper, this seems thinner than the original and little dustier in the finish.

brown pour with a medium foamy head.
aroma is dark fruit, rum cake. brown sugar and vanilla.
flavour is dark fruit again, molasses, vanilla oak, alc flavour is very soft.
Very drinkable.
bread, toast, amber, hazy, minimal head, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish, nice soft beer.

Dark brown with a red note. Light brown head, medium duration. Aroma of dark bread, dark fruit, yeasty, sweet sugars. Has a sweet flavor, lots of more dark bread, faint medicine perhaps, light pepper, more yeasty, light bitter finish. Heavy creamy texture. Soft carbonation.

2008 Bottle. Poured dark reddish/brown color with an average light brown frothy head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Medium to heavy complex dark fruit, wood, caramel and alcohol aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy complex sweet flavor with medium to heavy fruity sweet finish and a small bite of alcohol. Standout brew.

2008 Bottle at home from A Tutta Birra, Milan. Poured a murky russet colour with a fading sullied tan head which clung to the rim throughout. Nose was sweet and vinous and permeated by dark fruit, molasses and oak notes. Rich and full bodied, the flavour retained the traits apparent in the nose, with yeast, malt and spices apparent too. Sllid down.with a warming booze hit. A really good beer for sure, but I seem to recall enjoying the original rather more.

12 oz. 2008 bottle at near room temperature. Pours murky, dark reddish-brown with tan head. Nice lacing. Aromas of figs, raisins, caramel, dough. Very smooth and well balanced beer. A bit too much malt sweetness, though. I really enjoyed the first half of the bottle, but had to force the second half down.

11.2 oz bottle. Reserva, 2008 vintage, No4.

It is a beaut when it pours. It is black in the snifter with a plum purple/red colored hue when held to light. The head is off-white and tightly foamed. It sticks for a bit and recedes to a few spots of lacing.

The smell is full-force. It is HUGE and filled primarily with raisins, kirschwasser, almond extract, perfumey alcohol, brown sugar, vanilla, oak, and spice.

The flavor is much the same, just a really flavorful quad. It has tons of dark fruit flavors, caramel, toffee, dark bread, and dark candi sugar. There is also a hint of spiciness but nto really too much oak as there was in the smell. It is medium-full bodied with a prickling carbonation, an alcoholic tinge, and a dry finish. It is sweet, but not overly so, it is smooth and drinkable

A fantastic brew from a great brewery

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-13-2011 01:14:01

Serving: 330 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors.  It pours a very dark brown ruby highlights and a foamy, light tan head.  The nose is full of date and fig with some very nice spice and yeast notes.  Smells absolutely delightful.  The flavor is rich with dark caramel, fig, date, other dried fruit, and a dusty bitterness.  For some reason I dont think the oak quite fits.  There is a good bit of spice in there too.  Medium to rich body with average carbonation leading to a medium, fairly dry finish.  This 2008 bottle was pretty damn good.  I am eager to try another one.

2008. Dark amber hue with orange highlights, brilliant clarity, no head forms. Nose is oak and vanilla with sweet malts, dark fruits, and alcohol warmth. Flavor is sweet bread and grains with a very hot alcohol presence, opens up slightly to raisins and prunes, tones of oak from the aging, vanilla, and caramel, finishes sweet and hot. Full body, light carbonation, slick texture. A rich and sweet Belgian with plenty of depth from aging, delicious sipper.

Bottle, marked 2007. Pours a clear dark chocolate brown with reddish hues. Powerful aroma of raisins, figs, candi syrup, and brown sugar. Rich, sweet malty flavor. Carbonation was low with a silky smooth mouthfeel. One of the best beers Ive had in a long time.

08 bottle in a lovely Odell skinny tulip - perfect glass for this beer. Flows into the glass with a deep ruby tint which subsequently is nearly overwhelmed by deep brown. A foamy tan head sits on top. The nose packs a punch - candy sugar and bubblegum are dominant, with raisins, figs, plums, and caramel assisting and a hint of musty oak alongside. The flavor is less sugar-dominated and carries through more of the fruity, malty tones - raisins, chocolate brownies, dark cherries, plums. Finishes smooth, rich, and velvety with a little hint of tannins. The palate is smooth as butter the whole way through - perfect carbonation on this one. The head is quite persistent, especially considering its lower carbonation level. All in all, this beer satisfies nearly every whim a beer drinker could dream up. Regular Pannepot is great, too. But this one takes the cake.

2008 bottle courtesy of GL2814.  Pours slightly hazy reddish/mahogany with a very small tan head.  The aromas are slight bubblegum, oak, vanilla, caramel, raisin, and brandy.  The flavor is toffee and sweet raisin, woody and smoky oak, mild Chardonnay, and buttery oak.  Also present are slightly tart tamarind, slight grape notes, and peppery yeast and citrus.  Mmm.  Low carbonation and full-bodied, with a creamy, velvety mouthfeel.  Very good!  [611]

This was a very complex beer.  This is the first beer that I actually caught the bubblegum aroma.  Deep ruby color.  Strong oak barrel flavors and aromas.  Only really got a taste since I split a single bottle with a bunch of people.  Very good.

2007 vintage on tap at Maxs in Baltimore.  Chestnut brown pour with a slightly offwhite head.  Aroma is dark fruit, figs, caramel, molasses raisins, a bit of wood.  Flavor is malty, caramel, raisins, a touch of oxidation but in a good way.  Really nice beer.

I bought this beer to share with friends, not knowing how hard it is to come by in certain areas. Upon pouring it, one cant help but notice the dark color of the body, coupled with the beige foam on top. Its taste was complex, as the malts and spices blend, creating a taste difficult to describe. Sweet, fruity, caramel flavors, with a note of ginger and raisins. Its aroma was similar to that of plum pudding. After tasting it, I now understand why this is such a difficult beer to obtain.
Sample @BBF 2010. Nice beer! Strong hints of caramel and candy dominate the sip. So easy to drink!

Murky mahogany pour with a thin eggshell head that left a decent amount of lacing.  Nose is dark fruit, cocoa, and toffee.  Flavor shows caramel, raisin, brown sugar, and chocolate.  Medium mouthfeel with the ABV well hidden.

Bottle. Pours a hazy reddish brown with a thin tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, raisins, caramel, figs and brown sugar. Flavor was fairly sweet, rich and smooth with dark caramel, raisins, brown sugar, sweet dark fruit, light wood and a hint of toffee. A delicious and well balanced belgian strong

(Draft at Amesbury Alehouse) Served in a tulip (sort of). Pours very dark brown with a sort of reddish hue. Brown-amber highlights. Very little head that disappears to just some specks. Still-looking. Aroma is fairly mild but has notes of fruit (cherry/plum), chocolate, port and burgundy. Served a little too cold to get a good sense of the aroma. Mouthfeel is heavy and smooth, very light evidence of carbonation. Very little lacing. Flavor of dark fruits, chocolate and burgundy with some swirls of caramel as it warmed. Has the oak aging damped out much of the flavor and nuance I remember from regular Pannepot, along with the body, or did I just get an odd glass? At its best this sample reminded me of something like Southampton Abt 12 but then the next quaff reminded me of something like a flat Angels Share.

Bottle. 11.2 oz Split with James Pours a deep maroon amber with a thin, fizzy, creamy white head. Aroma of figs, grapes, sweet malts, green apples, honey, and sweet whiskey. Medium body. Soft, velvety palate with grapey, bready flavors and a bit of carbonation to balance the sweetness. FInishes juicy and rich, Great Belgian.

Bottle. Dark brown, very small and fully diminishing light brown head. Moderate, malty and caramel sweetish aroma, fruitiness and dark berries, light alcohol, faint spiciness. Body is medium to full, malty and caramel sweetish flavor, fruitiness and dark berries, light alcohol. Finish is average, malty and lightly sweetish, fruitiness and alcohol. OK not so sweet strong ale.

2008 bottle shared by BOLTZ  thanks J!  Pours murky brown with a thin tan head.  The nose is caramel, dark fruits, spice and light tobacco.  The taste is tobacco, toffee, dates and spice.  Medium bodied.  Good.

11.2 oz 2008 bottle.  Pours a dark sandy brown caramel color with a medium sized light beige head.  Aroma of faint dates, candied malt,  figs, brown sugar and light oak wood.  Taste of candied malt, dates, figs, dark sugar and light hints of oak.  Not bad, but not as good as the regular Pannepot.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2014 pours dark brown with a beige head. Aroma  of dark fruits, cherries, reisin, caramel malt, dark cocolate, I found all the stuff from the aroma in the taste along with some brown sugar, wood from the barrels and a sweet end.

12oz 2008 traded bottle. Pours a nice dark brown color with a thin khaki head and active carbonation. Absolutely classic Belgian aroma with yeast and sugars (honestly reminds me of Westy here). Classic flavor too. More sweetness and a little fruitiness. Maybe a little hot but warming and not obnoxious. Outstanding strong ale and well done.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2012 Bottle.  Pours a murky brown with a thin white head.  Aroma of bready malt, caramel, molasses, raisin, and dark fruits.  Flavor of vinous notes, bready malts, sweet malts, and lots of dark sweet fruits.  Sweet mouthfeel but not too sweet.  Unfortunately I havent had regular Pannepot in ages and dont remember it well (though according to my old ratings, both versions are very similar)  Nonetheless a tasty treat! 8/4/8/4/15 [3.9/5]
Update 4/19/2012: 2009 bottle. Aroma of dark fruits, fruitcake, and sweet molasses. Flavor is also sweet, sweeter than the original Pannepot, with spices in the finish. Tasty stuff!

Excellent beer.  Combines Pannepots huge fruity, malty flavors with drying oak overtones.  Raisins, plums, prunes, figs, dates, molasses, caramel, spice, sherry and wood.  The taste is fairly sweet but ends with a dry oak flavor.  Lush mouthfeel that, again, mostly dries out in the end.  Just makes me hunger all the more for the Grande Reserva.
Pours dark brown to ruby with a thin wispy off-white head. Notes of dark fruits, spice, clove, oak, wine. Full to heavy bodied, soft foamy carbonation. Very subtle and delightful.

Pours brown with a tan head collaring the glass and dusting the top. Nice malt with high alcohol notes.  Nice round mouthfeel. Lots of malt and alcohol. Not much oak here. Nothing stands out on this for me.

Bottle 33cl from brewery. A dark beer with no head. Smell is a bit vinous with champagne yeast notes. Aroma is medium sweet with toasted notes, spicy presence with a bit acid and vinous aroma as for Stille Nacht beer. Notes of apples, apricot, quite dry at the finish with a good dark chocolate presence.

11.2 oz bottle. Pours a very deep amber brown with a small off white froth. Aroma is very strong dark fruits, lots of plum, raisin, even a touch of overripe red grapes. Toasty with a noticeable candied fruit and some brown sugar. Flavor starts with some more very deep fruit, sherry, just a lot of fruity notes with a touch of acidity in the woody and slightly boozy finish. The toast and brown sugar linger after the swallow. Excellent beer, the oak is very nice and supports the rich fruit and tart notes nicely.
Dark garnet brown with a fizzy off white head. Chocolate molasses and brown sugar aroma. Bright palate. Tastes of citrus apple raisin vanilla caramel and mild chocolate with notes of brown sugar.

0.33 l bottle (vintage 2007), thanks hanniku and Timo A! Dark almost opaque reddish brown color. Thick sweet and sour aroma of soya sayce, raisins, plum licorice, toffee and bready yeast. Sweet taste of raisins, toffee, dark caramel, oak. Full body. Lots of umam taste, quite complex. Too sweet, could be dryer.

More mellow than the original Pannepot with notes of oak and sweet dark fruits.  The palate is soft and very smooth with a little less carbonation.  Completely balanced and everything works well together.  The oak has definitely resulted in a softer, smoother beer...but its hard to say if one version is better than the other.  Ill definitely have to revisit both soon.

2008 vintage.  Oak aging done very well.  Understated, for the type, aroma of sweet malts and a little smoke.  Alcohol not present.  Beautiful deep mahogany appearance and wonderfully elegant mouthfeel.  This is a classy beer, well-constructed.  Worth $9/11oz?

11.2oz 2008 vintage. Pours a deep mahogany with a nice off white head. Looks delicious. Great aroma of molasses, candied dark fruit, a touch of cocoa. Rich aroma. Perfect mouthfeel a medium to thick body balanced carbonation. Sweet and rich. Candied fruit of fig, plum, and raisin. A nice subtle spice.The ten percent is virtually unoticable. Brown sugar and vanilla contribute to a richness that is incredibly balanced and drinkable. Awesome, Ill have to set another aside and see how this matures. A pleasure to drink.

33 cl bottle, 2007 vintage. Pours redbrown, with a brown head that doesnt last long. Aromas of sweet fruit, sticky toffee, roast, some hints of wood, a bit spicy. Flavor is not as sweet as I expected (fortunately), but still somewhat sweet, a bit roasted & woody. Quite thick mouthfeel. Flavors linger on and a nice bitterness develops. One of my favorite Struise so far.

11.2 ounce bottle, 2008 vintage.  Served in a chalice, the beer pours a murky brown color with a thin 1/4 inch head that went away quickly.  However, there is a lot of lacing left on the glass.  Aroma is nice, sweet and strong, the brew smells like dark fruit, molasses, brown sugar, pears, caramel and bready malt and some oak.  The taste is similar to the aroma, the brew tastes like brown sugar, dark fruit, molasses, oak, apples, clove, caramel and bready malt.  Mouthfeel/body is medium/full, its a bit syrupy and coating with moderate carbonation.  Drinkability is pretty good, its very smooth and very easy to drink.  I think this is a good overall brew, I liked it a lot.

330 mL bottle from Sams Quik Stop in Durham (2008 bottle).  Muddy brown pour with a creamy off-white head.  Aroma of light bretty funkiness, raisins, and Belgian candi sugars.  The flavor is sweet with notes of brown sugar and caramel and lightly fruity apple, pear, and red grapes.  Alcohol is well hidden for the most part but does add to the overall flavor and mouthfeel of this beer.  Spot on for the style.

Bottle 2008: Pours cloudy brown (and I did let it sit for 2 days). Smells phenolic with bark and treacle notes. Well blow me that didnt taste anything like I thought it would. No taste-bud assault here; instead, its really mellow.  It has a syrupy body with a very low level of bitterness. Theres a sort of pine-resin and raisin flavour underpinning it with a slightly sour watery soy-sauce bite on the finish. If this were a UK beer I guess it would be an Old Ale.  Not really my thing but it would probably be quite nice as the final drink of a session just before bed.

2007 Bottle: @ Delirium Cafè Bryssels: Hazy Black/dark brown colour, with a athin white head. Aroma is caramel, and lots of raisins, coffee,and a nice citrus and caramelly in the ned. Flavor is  dominated of raisins,caramell, dark choclate,dust. Big body and a nice long mix of raisins and caramel finish. Werry nice complex beer this one

2008 Bottle.  Poured a very dark brownish black with a slightly oily light-tan head.  Aroma has lots of chocolate malt and coffee with plenty of oak.  Some nice fruity notes as well.  Some raisin and brown sugar.  Quite a complex aroma.  Taste is remarkably smooth for the alcohol amount.  Raisins, plumbs, dark fruits, oak, and vanilla all present.  The yeast gives a slightly tart note with distinctly Belgian flavors.  The chocolate malts and coffee are less noticeable in the taste than in the aroma.  Alcohol is slightly noticeable in the aftertaste, but it is still very smooth.  A few spices in the aftertaste as well, as if this beer couldnt get more complex.  This is a very good beer and the oak aging is a very nice touch.

Thanks to bmanning for sharing the 2007 vintage at a recent tasting with Azurelimits, Amyliz4, hhanson, and myself. 

A: Pours a light mahogany with chestnut and ruby hues both coming through. Small off-white head.

S: Belgian yeast with quite a bit of spiciness atop a bit of miscellaneous fruitiness. 

T: Nice spice notes of allspice, nutmeg, and clove in addition to a nice caramel malt sweetness coming through. Hints of vanilla and dark fruits.

M: Medium bodied with a very nice creaminess to it. Intriguing complexity.

D: Very drinkable, and one I definitely wish I had a bit more of to try. Another excellent beer in the Pannepot series.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-03-2010

2008 version, 330ml bottle from Westlakeview liquors. Enjoyable but missing something from the original. . Pours a deep brown with amber notes and a bubbly off white head. Carbonation missing. Aroma of molasses, dark fruits, vanilla, pice crust, spices and almonds. Flavor of caramel, dark fruits, vanilla, nuts and toasted malt along with some spices and earthy notes. Slightly less enjoyable than the original, could be my palate has had hundreds of more beers to compare than the last one. Still a top notch brew. Love Struise brews!
Poured hazy dark brown, dark fruits, malty, wood, spice, yeasty, little molasses.

It looks already great when you pour it out! The color makes the beer special (dark hazy brown). You can really taste the malt and the chocolaty taste afterwards. It has also hints of caramel, dried fruits and coffee.  You should only drink this beer on special occasions!

Tasted at Belmont Station. This beer is very rich and fruity.  There are hints of dried fruit like figs along with a nicespicy malty edge. The body is rich and this is an amazingly smooth beer for its strength.  The finish is malty and fruity with spicy notes of baking spices and just a touch of hops.  This is definitely a beer to sit down with and contemplate life.  It would probably go great with chocolate or other desserts.

11.2oz bottle in a shaker.  Pours deep brown with a lacy, off-white head.  Aroma of spice, chocolate, roasted malts, and slight hoppiness.  This is a great Belgian ale, and the oak flavor really comes in on the finish.  The alcohol is not too strong, but you can tell its there.  Definitely recommended.

2008 bottle. Dark red brown; shy head, in stark contrast to regular Pannepot. Fruitcake aroma, reminds me of des Rocs Brune. Taste - lots of residual sugars, rummy, hot and boozy. Fruitcake again. Woodier than regular Pannepot. Pretty much a completely different beer, still good, but not so unique.

Draft. Pours hazy brown with a small tan head. Flavor is caramel, dark fruit, cherries, apricot, oak barrel, vanilla. Very light and easy to drink, but less complex than the original. An excellent beer.

Pours hazy reddish brown with white head, thanks caleb! Aroma and flavor is complex, with notes of pepper, apricot, dark fruit, oak, vanilla, and some caramel. Sweet finish. Good, but I liked the original better.

11.2 oz. bottle 2008 vintage.  Pours a dark brown color with a creamy beige head.  The aroma is rather soft, but very much like regular Pannepot.  The flavor has notes of oak, nutmeg, dark fruits, brown sugar and vanilla.   The finish is drier and slightly sour, and seemingly more complex than regular Pannepot.  Full bodied and very smooth; this is a great sipper.  I think that overall this is as good as the regular Pannepot, but for different reasons.  I have a 750 ml from 2005 in the cellar that I will have to crack some day.

2008 bottle. Pour is dark brown with a quick kahki head that dissapears. Aroma has a bitter sour malt yeasty scent along with some brown sugar and brunt mollasses. Taste is nice dark fruit and brown sugar along with more mollasses and malt. Palate is medium feel with nice carbonation.

As pictured. Pours burgundy with orange glints and a patchy beige swirl of head. Plum brandy, spiced apple, muscovado and English confectionery aroma (brown and white Allsorts, liquorice boot laces). Tastes like Highgate with a shot of Ricard; slick and cake-accented with bags of brown sugar, liquorice and aniseed. Some toasted bread and caramel in the aftertaste. Slick, tasty, very restrained oak. Nothing special.

2008 vintage served on tap at OBriens during SDBW at Attack of the Barrel night. The appearance is a cloudy deeper amber brown. The aromas are caramel, bready, dark fruits, baking spices. The flavors are sweet malts, brown sugar, candied sugar, dark fruits. The mouth is fuller bodied but a little flatter. The bottle conditioning Ive had on the other varieties add a lot of good carbonation that is missing here. Tasty brew still.

Hazy brown, with yeasty chunks and a light brown cm of thick foam, with strong lace and legs. Aroma is slightly vinous with a touch of woody cherry notes. Taste is richly alcoholic, with apple and pear esters, and woody coffee astringency into the finish.  Not exactly a calliope of flavors, this is rather narrow-band, and well carbonated. $10/11.2oz

Sample at Borefts Beer Festival 2010. Pours a clear and reddish brown beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt, hops and spices. The flavor is malt, sweetness and spices. The palate is sweet. Overall a good beer.

11/10/10 notes: Pours hazelnut brown, slightly hazy with small cream colored head.  Aroma has fantastic depth, focused around sweet malt, mixed nuts, oak and dates.  Maybe some cinnamon notes thrown in as well.  Palate is perfect in its decadent creaminess.  Flavor follows aroma, and the richness of it all is absolutely fantastic.  Lingering oak, sweet bread french toast with caramelized brown sugar on finish.  Similar to regular Pannepot for sure, perhaps the enhanced oak and hint of tartness are new.

Rating #500. 2008 bottle. Nearly opaque mahogany color with a small bone colored head that resembles a thick liquid. The aroma is loaded with figs, plum, cherry, toffee, and caramel. The flavor mirrors the aroma, with tart cherries, mellow alcohol, and a woody finish. Soft and creamy mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Very tasty stuff, well worth the wait.

2008 bottle.  Murky light brown in color with a small off white head.  Dark fruit, brown sugar and cola aromas.  Fig, cherry, and grape, with big oak and sweet malt/brown sugar characteristics.  A great beer....

Pours brown with a small just-off-white bubbly head. Aroma is much like the normal Pannepot but heavier on the alcohol and on the wood notes. Flavor is not as good as the original in my opinion, kind of flat and the wood characteristics can overpower the dark fruits and sweetness that made the other one so outstanding. Good, but not as good as the original in my opinion.

Pours a cola brown, same as regular Pannepot.  Not much of a head on this one, just some scant bubbles.  Its muddy looking.  Aroma shows some slight dark fruits, vanilla, brown sugar, skittles.  Definite oak presence.  Some cocoa is in there too.  This could use some more carbonation to bring out the aromas.  Based on the nose alone I dont think its as complex and interesting as regular Pannepot.  Flavor is a little flat with some grapes and other fruits.  This is good I guess but nowhere near as good as the original.

Bottle: A dark mahogany ruby color with a touch of ruby, light head, light carbonation and light lacing. The nose is chewy with big fruits; fig, cherry, juniper, raspberry and light tart yeast. Chewy malts and rye in the flavor with a fresh subtle hint of bitterness to balance but a continuation of the sweet fruity malty glory. Very little alcohol notes. Excellent. Thank you footbalm for bringing up this gem!
Bottle. Pours cola brown. Nose of dried apricot, malts and spice. Taste is full bodied caramel apple, dried fruits, coffee, raisin and nuts. Very delicious and well-balanced.
Pours copper with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, alcohol and fruit. Flavour is caramel, alcohol, fruit, marcipan and plum.

Pours a deep burgundy color with a big head and lots of lace. The aroma is brown sugar and earthy notes with some raisins, some floral notes, and a good nutty and spicy character. The flavor is raisny again but has a nice spicy and earthy bit with some molasses and a warming booziness. The palate is very full but a little bit slick. Really a damn rich delicious beer.
2008. Very raisiny, through and through. A tiny bit of chocolate. Awesomely balanced and dry. Slightly dirty. Spicy raisin fills your nostrils.

Bottle split with Tony. Pours a murky, hazy brown body with nice thin light brown lacing. Aroma is sweet malt and Belgian candy? Mouthfeel is smooth, slightly carbonated with notes of spice, clove, wheat...solid beer - still think the original PANNEPOT PWNS.

Had compliments of james generosity and good looks. Pour is a nice dark brown with a thin cloudy cover of head over the beer with minor lacing. Aroma is amazing balance of sweet malts, oak, alcohol, and cherry. Flavor is cherry malts, alcohol, and some hints of wood and bread. Nice brew indeed.
Pours a murky brown color with an off-white soapy head.  Has an aroma of brown sugar with hints of raisans and alcohol.  Medium mouthfeel.  Has a bitter boozy taste with notes of brown sugar and oak.

33cl Bottle 2008. Dark brown colour with a medium-sized beige head. Aroma is sweet malt, raisins, oak and some fruits. Flavour is very sweet with notes of raisins, malt, oak, alcohol, spices and yeast. Quite smooth, medium to full body.

10/16/10.  2008 vintage.  Slightly sour sweet caramel malty aroma with a hint of grapes and woody tannins.  Very sweet caramel flavor with definite maltiness, sweet grape juice, and brown sugar with a touch of oak.  Was expecting more out of this, honestly.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2011 Original review below, revised review after a year plus of aging:
Aromas and flavor have added some pretty good oxidation notes... sherry & prunes/plum.  Im not picking up the wateriness that I noted earlier and it is a much fuller and lovely.  
Original score: 7 4 8 4 14
Bottle.  Thin brown body with lots of carbonation and aromas of oak, brown sugar, dates and raisins.  Flavor is a watery mix of the above that is pretty disappointing compared to my expectations.  A little too thin, a little too sweet, a little too directionless.  Still good, but expecting more.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle. 2008 vintage. Pours a dark brown slightly murky color with a tan head that quickly settles to form a nice collar around the glass. Raisin, grape, and other dark fruit aromas in the nose. Maybe a slight malt aroma as well. Medium mouthfeel. Dark fruit apparent in the taste with notes of raisin and plum. No real oak tastes all that much. Some booze evident. Overall, not a bad beer but not as good as I would have thought or wanted.

Draft, 2008 vintage.  Muddy brown body topped by minimal beige head.  Aroma is mild, some raisin.  Taste is moderately sweet, raisin, some vinous/wood, anise, light cinnamon, bittersweet chocolate.  Smooth medium-full body, minimal carbonation.

07 bottle.   Some gushing but not infected.  Thick brown head.  Clean, even lacing down the side of the glass.  Beautiful aroma - coffee, spice, candied sugar, cinnamon dough, slight leather, and maybe barely noticeable oak.  Just a wonderful smell - no overbearing, clove-heavy belgian yeast.  Not too sweet.  Man - the smell is so damn good!  Light and smooth in the mouth - figs, cinnamon, an overall lightly sugared spice, and a whisp of alcohol. I can taste the oak influence not so much as overt oak flavor but in the rounding and mellowing of the other flavors.  Spectacular beer - I get it.  Amazing stuff.

UPDATED: AUG 23, 2014 A  very dark brown ale but the head is almost white. Caramel, coffee, syrup, berries, vanilla, black tea.... you name it. After having consumed some of this I am left with a warm, cozy feeling. All I am missing is a fireplace and a non-nagging woman next tome.

Bottle:
Nice off white foamy head on top of a dark brown beer.
Smell is a mix of dark fruits, brown sugars, sweet malts, wood and spices, 
Taste dark fruits (prunes, raisin), brown sugars, yeast, spices and toasted malts. Also hints of wood, herbs, toffee and bitter/sour.
Bit soft in taste compared to the regular Pannepot, but very drinkable with a smooth and slight (sweet)bitter (after)taste.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: On tap at the Trappist. I was a little disappointed in this one. It poured a muddy brown with ruby highlights and a thin off white head. The aroma was lots of dark dried fruit and hard candy. The flavor was the same with a strong alcoholic finish. This wasnt sweet at all, though.  The oak was only mildly noticeable. A very refined brew, but I was looking for a richer, more yeasty kick.

33cl bottle from the binnys next to Goose.   I was pretty psyched to find this after class a couple days ago.   Dark brown with a medium-sized beige head that settles into a persistent slick of foam.   Rich dried fruit aroma with a very aged, dry, almost syrupy quality.   Lightly spiced underneath that, but its hard to tell with what, which is how I like it.   A light touch of butter once things warm up, which could be diacetyl or could be the oak, and Im guessing its the oak.   Adds a really nice richness actually.   There is brighter than dried fruit wuality as well, though it is well integrated and reminds me a bit of cooked apple and peach.   The flavor is rich and sweet with a spicy fruitcake quality and a touch of burnt molasses.   Hardly and alcohol shows, and this is way too easy to drink, drying out just slightly in the finish and not leaving uncomfortable sweetness behind.   Oak is slightly noticeable in the finish, but is subtle overall.    Full bodied with medium but very fine carbonation.   A very nice beer on the whole.   The barrel aging gives it a nice roundness and complexity without sticking out at all.

Pours a dark reddish brown color with a light tope foamy head. Nose is pumpkin seeds, root beer, licorice, vanilla, dark toffee candies, and green herbs. Taste boozy chocolate bitter chocolate syrup, baking spices, sherry, raisins, and candied sugar. Not overwhelming. This beer show restraint and is good, and not overly carbonated.

330ml Bottle (2006 Vintage):  Aroma of malt, raisins, light dark ripe fruit, slight wood, and plums.  Not very aromatic.  Poured brown/very deep amber in color with a small, tan head that diminished, except for around the edges.  Cloudy.  Opaque.  Not sparkling.  Flavor is heavily sweet.  Tastes of malt, dark ripe fruit, light wood, slight caramel, slight raisin, dark ripe fruit, dust, and yeast.  Full body.  Slick, oily texture.  Soft carbonation.  Malt, raisin, dark ripe fruit, yeast, and light wood finish.  10%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2014 Re-rate Bottle at Irrreale. 
Dark sugar, roast grain, lactic, port aroma
Black, brown cream
Light wooden, vanilla, molassis, berry flavor, resinny citrus
Fullbodied, dry, mellow mouthfeel 
Elegant, not as complex as I remember though


Re-rate 2008 bottle in Cafe Abseits 2012.
6 4 8 3 15
Dark sugar, plum nose
Claret, low head
Cognac, molassis, roast, a bit allspice, clove, plum and wood aftertaste
mellow slick mouthfeel
Spicy aftertaste, plum retronasal 

Old rating 9 3 9 3 18
Copenhagen beerfestival 2007 - 2006 bottle.  Wooden and fine estery aroma. Cloudy brow, with a brown head. Preserved fruit, orangepeel, chocolate covered raspberries, wood. Has a sherrylike wooden dryness.

2008: Black cherries, molasses, and oak on the nose, candi overtones. Clear walnut brown, thin yellow head, good lacing. Dark roasted malt flavor initially with the subtle presence of candi sugar and vanilla. Maraschino and oak finish. Good transitons, great balancecreamy mouthfeel. Very good well rounded beer.

2008 Vintage from the Struise Webshop. Pours a deep mahogany brown with tan head that dissipates. Nose is distinctly Belgian, obviously. Notes of plum, cherry, green apple and oak. Vanilla and buckwheat honey as well. Very nice nose on this one, perhaps some coriander and cardamom notes as well. On taste, nice tartness at the front, white pepper, raisins and some green apple fading into roast. Pretty seamless integration of flavors. Alcohol is also present, though it fades pretty well. Not overwhelming at all. Pretty solid beer.

Dark brown pour with thin tan head.  Aroma of belgian sugars, nice oak, a bit of caramel and dark fruit.  Some apparent alcohol.  Flavor has all the nice quad notes with strong wood, lots of belgian sugars and nice dried fruit.  Raisins, plums, maybe a bit vinous.  Nice full mouthfeel, good carbonations.  Good carbonation.  Finishes sweet and oaky.  Easily one of the best beers Ive had from Struise.

2007 Bottle @ home. Deep, almost solid brown with faint red glow, medium sized deep brown head.
Aroma is peat, raisin, liquorice, roasted malt, hint of wine/grape and lots more.
Flavour is very intense, thick creamy goodness, lots of fruit, lots of liquorice, smokey sidenote, roasted malt, some coffee, alcohol warm up the throat in the finish, which lasts forever. Perfect carbonation. Great reward for a hard days work. And a good nightcap as well.

From a 2008 edition bottle that opened with rather nice pop.  Color is murky brown with ruby highlights,  and a small khaki head that quickly fades.  Wonderful wine-like aroma with anise, chocolate, and candy sugar.  There almost seems to be a smoke characteristic to the aroma.  Really complex and enjoyable.  Flavor is also somewhat wine-like with an almost cake frosting like sugary sweetness, and oak in the finish.  I could go for more of this anytime!

2008 11.2oz bottle.  Pours a deep, hazy, mahogany with a small khaki head.  Big nose on this beer.  Notes of wine, wood, pears, bread, spices and doughy yeast on the nose. A lot going on here.  However, I feel this beer still needs some time to sit and round out.  The taste relies heavily on the yeast with brown sugar, fruit (both light and dark), toffee, vanilla, and wine soaked wood with a slick mouthfeel and long finish.  Quite nice.

Bottle 2008.  Aroma has notes of caramel, fig, oak, dark bread and Belgian yeast.  Dark brown murky hue with a smaller off-white head that mostly diminished and left little lace.  Flavor is medium/heavy sweet and smooth.  Palate is medium/heavy bodied and watery, almost flat, mouth-feel.   Overall a very smooth and pleasant brew that has very little bitterness and while bigger bodied it never offends and remains balanced.  Complex and enjoyable.

Bottle from Sams in Durham.  Pours very dark brown with a lovely light mocha head.  Nose is dark summer fruits, mild cherries, figs, raisins, and bitter chocolate.  I wanted some more of the bitter chocolate to come out on the taste, but the taste matched the nose in that the sweetness won out slightly.  Some more tannins and a nice and dry finish were a nice added touch, though.  Lovely soft and dry palate.  Great beer, but Im not sure its worth the extra bucks compared to the non-oaked Pannepot.
bottle, thanks to SS, dark walnuts color with creamy foam, aroma of smooth nutty, caramel and dark fruit , flavor is much the same with a smokiness to the finish

Bottle from the brewery/shop in Oostvleteren. Pours a deep, dense mahogany body with virtually no retention to speak of. Aroma is vanilla, molasses, hints of raisins and caramel, with some boozy notes. Taste is velvety smooth and filled with caramel, toast, vinous grape-peel notes, hints of nuts and booze. Some sherry notes in the aftertaste. Warming alcohol. A very solid ale from De Struise, and a worthy flagship - or fishin boat - for the brewery. :-)

2008 Bottle 33cl batch A4DD.  I like the new labels but I miss the old ones all the same.  Pours a gorgeous glowing shinny mahogany with a perfect fine thick fizzy frothy light tan head with plenty of lacing.  Again, this is a completely different animal than Pannepot or Panneput.  Aroma is densely fruity, rich berries, super plummy trappist yeast, lovely undertones of vanilla and oak, red wine?, pleasant alcohol notes elevate each aroma, lovely balance, light chocolate tootsie roll, and finishing with the berry note.  Flavor follows, fairly young, which I like, plummy, some bitterness upfront that goes away with each sip, so much trappist yeast character, lightly soda poppy, cola, mr pibb, nice berry flavor that isnt too tart, a light vanilla creaminess, some bitterness lingers in the finish, light nuttiness in the aftertaste, so similar to the Westy and Rochefort, almost more so than anything else Ive tried from Struise or anyone.  Body is near perfect, medium bodied, soft slightly sharp fizzy carbonation, just slightly milky in the body.  I wonder how my 2005 bottle is doing... it certainly needs opening.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2010 Bottle, Vintage 2008.  Muddy hazelnut brown pour with some nice tan lace lasting throughout.
